The multiple images used in our model are marked on the image. System 1 was spectroscopically measured by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. (2010)</a> to be at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 2.84 and system 2 was spectroscopically measured by them to be at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 1.78. On the image, we overlay the critical curves for a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2, enclosing a critical area with equivalent Einstein radius of \u223c130 kpc at the cluster redshift.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f19\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 19</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-f19.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=GKvYuSKIKieekPHzGuoytDm5SapXJliERs36lVthvU9bYmQmQ5vR2ZSXQ2cnKtz2OwqJAgGdFbl6~2XCS0mCSku~EFC-C6eissF01dV0OYyV7NWVsRY65r4LtBPexi-PKh~zePhR2R6QfDsMXI0LcDbW~ixs7Fa33ZmyBokejptMqfQJGxYb4bCSaC909y94yVaUaNmNS~sX0XuZjYNGUswl~n7QHUB6TELi0z6kuM7T38813MYHAsaq0GH6SQiblXW1quJ6qt-XzMpilHN9hB9Y4isbWVTGOBHHcdsPc2mFcA-0U92urB6eB8EFXfQcuvk-iOuKP7L72c0tR5d4Lw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Galaxy cluster MACS J1423.8+2404 (z = 0.543) imaged with Hubble/ACS F555W and F814W bands. The multiple images used in our model are marked on the image. System 1 was spectroscopically measured by Limousin et al. (2010) to be at zs = 2.84 and system 2 was spectroscopically measured by them to be at zs = 1.78. On the image, we overlay the critical curves for a source redshift of zs\u223c 2, enclosing a critical area with equivalent Einstein radius of \u223c130 kpc at the cluster redshift.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f19.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16545184/mnras0410-1939-f19.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f19.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16545184\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/mnras0410-1939-f19.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&Signature=bh9NpmK4iSDlSmAhI77CeokoTxXA2y2O~7r6L8ZF5w-4ic5W86tYPgpCEcKlGvrplhqfIBsjsiIGcW1nFrU8W8gpFORc-92-HzRXnBo-QzIQgTYGox0MO6ZSyIgyce33oESBdkCciEqwb1dY5I01i4nnYJojRreulyTCBTgRXnx4lBDzjjY2o~Iv3TodLyeVdfJ9kgX1j6QgcmzK93ZtAvRmy1ItuIdrry3yHrvf5IyO0NK~i1OKVL40z5YGB7ckftSH2~BgHKAcWhFpQJRNuN~Kou3-y6BRGOirNdCW7C6AfPXdhsqqlIGSgwhcyFsbUD4ChJf3O6f1PkQxOYO0BQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16545184&ar=963929&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f19.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy cluster MACS J1423.8+2404 (<em>z</em> = 0.543) imaged with <em>Hubble</em>/ACS <em>F555W</em> and <em>F814W</em> bands. The multiple images used in our model are marked on the image. System 1 was spectroscopically measured by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. Axes are in ACS pixels (0.05 arcsec pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>), and a 20-arcsec scale bar is overplotted.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"16545190\" scrollto-destination=\"16545190\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t2\" data-id=\"t2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary and results of the SL analysis. Part of the following data are based on <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al.</a> (2007; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>). Column 3: Effective Einstein radius, in arcsec (simply the square root of the area enclosed within the critical curves divided by \u03c0); Column 4: Effective Einstein radius, in kpc, for <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2. An uncertainty of \u0394<em>z</em>\u00b1 0.5 in the estimated source redshift results in a typical \u223c10 per cent deviation in the lensing distance ratio, and usually up to such deviation also in the Einstein radii. Column 5: Mass enclosed within the critical curves, in 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. The quoted errors correspond to the different models. They do not include the source redshift uncertainty where exists. An uncertainty of \u0394<em>z</em>\u223c 0.5 can cause a typical mass uncertainty of <sup>+50</sup><sub>\u221210</sub> per cent; Column 6: <em>M</em>/<em>L<sub>B</sub></em>, in (M/L)<sub>\u2299</sub>, fluxes were converted to luminosities using the Luminous Red Galaxies (LRG) template described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ben\u00edtez et al. (2009)</a>; Column 7: Lower limit of the highly magnified (&gt;10\u00d7) area for a high-<em>z</em> source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 8, in arcmin<sup>2</sup>; and Column 8: image-plane rms, in arcsec; for more details, see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td>MACS\u00a0</td><td><em>z</em>\u00a0</td><td>\u03b8<sub>e</sub> (arcsec)\u00a0</td><td>\u2243 <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> href=\"/view-large/16545190\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t2\" data-id=\"t2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary and results of the SL analysis. Part of the following data are based on <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al.</a> (2007; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>). Column 3: Effective Einstein radius, in arcsec (simply the square root of the area enclosed within the critical curves divided by \u03c0); Column 4: Effective Einstein radius, in kpc, for <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2. An uncertainty of \u0394<em>z</em>\u00b1 0.5 in the estimated source redshift results in a typical \u223c10 per cent deviation in the lensing distance ratio, and usually up to such deviation also in the Einstein radii. Column 5: Mass enclosed within the critical curves, in 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. The quoted errors correspond to the different models. They do not include the source redshift uncertainty where exists. An uncertainty of \u0394<em>z</em>\u223c 0.5 can cause a typical mass uncertainty of <sup>+50</sup><sub>\u221210</sub> per cent; Column 6: <em>M</em>/<em>L<sub>B</sub></em>, in (M/L)<sub>\u2299</sub>, fluxes were converted to luminosities using the Luminous Red Galaxies (LRG) template described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ben\u00edtez et al. (2009)</a>; Column 7: Lower limit of the highly magnified (&gt;10\u00d7) area for a high-<em>z</em> source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 8, in arcmin<sup>2</sup>; and Column 8: image-plane rms, in arcsec; for more details, see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td>MACS\u00a0</td><td><em>z</em>\u00a0</td><td>\u03b8<sub>e</sub> (arcsec)\u00a0</td><td>\u2243 <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 25</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-f25.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=IWmanrY7jjSDAs9EowPGa~kNn1G2bbBfS7zQ8YMB9EPsUlkeWy8fv2dzhwD2PUs~2M290KRP9H9sRNF~Ar1mSFDqmSutjht1m~ApOnX0QdlsNz9X7OWlS757ese7e7YUJS4H3kMiNdZInSlR27gyxJY4JlhxTSBifA4lmXdqJkhksiD2chMyFlyvDrpoKK5scHznzWlAW3wN1RelnArJkfnFXqIT28Ej5LSblva0NGAlFy3avQZJDdSEN3fnoiryTLOKZ7OXA2dWOVPAFpAytFfadQQgo3cEFYqSoHBTFcEDOzKRP4qB1I0BG56ZK4G0M~tBt-KV74mYNs7iLdIb1Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Einstein radius distribution. This histogram shows the number of clusters per bin, where six equally spaced bins were used to divide the range 11\u201355 arcsec. The solid curve is the expected distribution of Einstein radii as calculated in Section 4.4 for the \u039bCDM model, incorporating both the scatter on the LX\u2013M relation and the projection bias from lensing. We multiply the resulting theoretical dN/d\u03b8e curve by the width of the bins to normalize it. The observed distribution is skewed to larger Einstein radii than predicted. The median values of both the observed and the theoretical distributions are plotted on the histogram in a blue dashed line and a black dot\u2013dashed line, respectively.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f25.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16545191/mnras0410-1939-f25.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f25.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16545191\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/mnras0410-1939-f25.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&Signature=teN5GosoH6kmLf8I7yxd3n9DBwMkfe3mrIXoGe1u9flGZQPZYkJ~MkA6tAHUK-Cxkg42kPGr4salLOt04G06jpIqjSGhG5eGjGUfEs5Dkgi-V2o1vFT5iMQoc5w2GSqRXb1vAGVE2s6rKSIojOTENw1oiTfDEgyJkOtskE7Jm2m5H~BYLv5v9ZqYg677NPFnLpQb9f-vNIvJ0n8G5ePQzFcLZHuWYuM8WBOpcmqSKtefLna8yfVndDfQ47Y7-V79Kyd66WlNp5G75zWyt20C6UbBQ2R-sXCmCqY2Ydpvqp4uzSPKF7AmtYLW91JkEPSv4uev5MBI1PmQ-S~Gw0tbbA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16545191&ar=963929&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f25.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Einstein radius distribution. This histogram shows the number of clusters per bin, where six equally spaced bins were used to divide the range 11\u201355 arcsec. The solid curve is the expected distribution of Einstein radii as calculated in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.4</a> for the \u039bCDM model, incorporating both the scatter on the <em>L</em><sub>X</sub>\u2013<em>M</em> relation and the projection bias from lensing. We multiply the resulting theoretical d<em>N</em>/d\u03b8<sub>e</sub> curve by the width of the bins to normalize it. The observed distribution is skewed to larger Einstein radii than predicted. The median values of both the observed and the theoretical distributions are plotted on the histogram in a blue dashed line and a black dot\u2013dashed line, respectively.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f25\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 25</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-f25.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=IWmanrY7jjSDAs9EowPGa~kNn1G2bbBfS7zQ8YMB9EPsUlkeWy8fv2dzhwD2PUs~2M290KRP9H9sRNF~Ar1mSFDqmSutjht1m~ApOnX0QdlsNz9X7OWlS757ese7e7YUJS4H3kMiNdZInSlR27gyxJY4JlhxTSBifA4lmXdqJkhksiD2chMyFlyvDrpoKK5scHznzWlAW3wN1RelnArJkfnFXqIT28Ej5LSblva0NGAlFy3avQZJDdSEN3fnoiryTLOKZ7OXA2dWOVPAFpAytFfadQQgo3cEFYqSoHBTFcEDOzKRP4qB1I0BG56ZK4G0M~tBt-KV74mYNs7iLdIb1Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Einstein radius distribution. This histogram shows the number of clusters per bin, where six equally spaced bins were used to divide the range 11\u201355 arcsec. The solid curve is the expected distribution of Einstein radii as calculated in Section 4.4 for the \u039bCDM model, incorporating both the scatter on the LX\u2013M relation and the projection bias from lensing. We multiply the resulting theoretical dN/d\u03b8e curve by the width of the bins to normalize it. The observed distribution is skewed to larger Einstein radii than predicted. The median values of both the observed and the theoretical distributions are plotted on the histogram in a blue dashed line and a black dot\u2013dashed line, respectively.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f25.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16545191/mnras0410-1939-f25.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f25.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16545191\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/mnras0410-1939-f25.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&Signature=teN5GosoH6kmLf8I7yxd3n9DBwMkfe3mrIXoGe1u9flGZQPZYkJ~MkA6tAHUK-Cxkg42kPGr4salLOt04G06jpIqjSGhG5eGjGUfEs5Dkgi-V2o1vFT5iMQoc5w2GSqRXb1vAGVE2s6rKSIojOTENw1oiTfDEgyJkOtskE7Jm2m5H~BYLv5v9ZqYg677NPFnLpQb9f-vNIvJ0n8G5ePQzFcLZHuWYuM8WBOpcmqSKtefLna8yfVndDfQ47Y7-V79Kyd66WlNp5G75zWyt20C6UbBQ2R-sXCmCqY2Ydpvqp4uzSPKF7AmtYLW91JkEPSv4uev5MBI1PmQ-S~Gw0tbbA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16545191&ar=963929&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f25.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Einstein radius distribution. The solid curve is the expected distribution of Einstein radii as calculated in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.4</a> for the \u039bCDM model, incorporating both the scatter on the <em>L</em><sub>X</sub>\u2013<em>M</em> relation and the projection bias from lensing.
