         </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16545143 id=\"16545143\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present the results of a strong-lensing analysis of a complete sample of 12 very luminous X-ray clusters at <em>z</em> &gt; 0.5 using <em>HST</em>/ACS images. Our modelling technique has uncovered some of the largest known critical curves outlined by many accurately predicted sets of multiple images. The distribution of Einstein radii has a median value of \u224328 arcsec (for a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2), twice as large as other lower <em>z</em> samples, and extends to 55 arcsec for MACS J0717.5+3745, with an impressive enclosed Einstein mass of 7.4 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. We find that nine clusters cover a very large area (&gt;2.5 arcmin<sup>2</sup>) of high magnification (\u03bc &gt; 10\u00d7) for a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 8, providing primary targets for accessing the first stars and galaxies. We compare our results with theoretical predictions of the standard \u039b cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) model which we show systematically fall short of our measured Einstein radii by a factor of \u22431.4, after accounting for the effect of lensing projection. Nevertheless, a revised analysis, once arc redshifts become available, and similar analyses of larger samples, is needed in order to establish more precisely the level of discrepancy with \u039bCDM predictions.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: general&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: general</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: individual: MACS z &gt; 0.5 sample&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: individual: MACS <em>z</em> &gt; 0.5 sample</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;dark matter&quot;\">dark matter</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16545145 id=\"16545145\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Massive galaxy clusters provide several means for independently examining any viable cosmological model. Cluster samples used for this purpose are usually complete in terms of X-ray and redshift measurements, such as the RDCS (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b80\" data-open=\"b80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Rosati et al. 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Borgani et al. 1999</a>) and the MACS survey (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b29\" data-open=\"b29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling, Edge &amp; Henry 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. 2007</a>), that we examine here with lensing. Ideally, controlled samples of clusters with reliable lensing masses would allow the most direct comparison with theory but these are presently still in their infancy with only a handful of clusters discovered in wide-field weak-lensing searches (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b95\" data-open=\"b95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Taylor et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b100\" data-open=\"b100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Wittman et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b62\" data-open=\"b62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Massey et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b68\" data-open=\"b68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Miyazaki et al. 2007</a>), and may be often subject to projection biases (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b41\" data-open=\"b41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hennawi &amp; Spergel 2005</a>). Weak-lensing surveys should have the advantage of being approximately volume limited over the redshift range 0.1 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 1.0, where the lensing distance ratio has a broad maximum.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Ongoing measurements of the Sunyaev\u2013Zel\u2019dovich (SZ) effect (which has already been detected in many tens of clusters, including some at relatively high redshifts <em>z</em>\u223c 0.9, e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b51\" data-open=\"b51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">LaRoque et al. 2006</a>) in a large number of clusters over a wide redshift range should improve upon X-ray selection, due to the redshift independence of the effect (though clearly high redshift clusters are relatively less well resolved). Also, since the insensitivity of the effect to internal gas density variations will not be biased as with X-ray flux selection towards systems with luminous shocked gas, measurements should better correlate with cluster masses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lensing (SL) is nearly always seen in sufficiently detailed observations of massive clusters. Einstein radii derived from such observations provide a reliable projected mass within the observed Einstein radius, which depends only on fundamental constants, <em>G</em> and <em>c</em>, and knowledge of the lens and source distances. Constraining the inner mass profile from SL is much harder, requiring many sets of multiple images covering a wide range of source redshift, to overcome inherent lensing degeneracy between the gradient of the mass profile and the scaling of the bend angle with source distance. SL-based mass profiles have been usefully constrained for only several clusters producing reliable mass maps (e.g. Abell 370, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b47\" data-open=\"b47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. 1993</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b76\" data-open=\"b76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. 2010a</a>; Abell 901, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b22\" data-open=\"b22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Deb et al. 2010</a>; Abell 1689, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b14\" data-open=\"b14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b20\" data-open=\"b20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Coe et al. 2010</a>; Abell 1703, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b58\" data-open=\"b58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. 2008</a>; Cl 0024+1654, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b56\" data-open=\"b56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Liesenborgs et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009b</a>; MS 2137.3\u22122353, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b38\" data-open=\"b38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gavazzi et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b67\" data-open=\"b67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Merten et al. 2009</a>; RX J1347, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brada\u010d et al. 2008a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b40\" data-open=\"b40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Halkola et al. 2008</a>; SDSS J1004+4112, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b84\" data-open=\"b84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sharon et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b57\" data-open=\"b57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Liesenborgs et al. 2009</a>; \u2018The bullet cluster\u2019, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brada\u010d et al. 2006</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In quite a few of these clusters, there is a significant inconsistency between the Einstein radius directly measured from SL analyses and the Einstein radius predicted from model profiles fitted to weak-lensing measurements of the same clusters, often subject to background selection and dilution problems over a wide radial range (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b63\" data-open=\"b63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Medezinski et al. 2010</a>), though more so towards the SL regime, where the degree of contamination by cluster members is often poorly corrected. The importance of a SL analysis of a significant sample is clear, especially in the statistical aspect, where the modelling method is similar for all examined clusters and thus supplies a coherent view for objective comparison (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b77\" data-open=\"b77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. 2010b</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The development of SL modelling methods has gained momentum in response to the improvement in data quality since the discoveries of the first giant arcs (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b61\" data-open=\"b61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Lynds &amp; Petrosian 1986</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b90\" data-open=\"b90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Soucail et al. 1987</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b48\" data-open=\"b48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. 1996</a>). Most methods can be classified as \u2018parametric\u2019, if based on physical parametrization, and as \u2018non-parametric\u2019 if they are \u2018grid based\u2019 (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.4</a> in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b19\" data-open=\"b19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Coe et al. 2008</a>, and references therein). Still, many of these methods include too many parameters to be well constrained by the number of initially known multiply-lensed systems. Here we use ACS imaging to identify new multiply-lensed systems in order to constrain the mass distributions and define the critical curves of the sample, motivated by the successful minimalistic approach of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b14\" data-open=\"b14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. (2005)</a> to lens modelling. In following work (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009b</a>), we presented an improved modelling method which involved only six free parameters enabling easier constraint, since the number of constraints has to be equal or larger to the number of parameters in order to get a reliable fit. Two of these parameters are primarily set to reasonable values so only four of these parameters have to be constrained initially, which sets a very reliable starting-point using obvious systems. The mass distribution is therefore primarily well constrained, uncovering many multiple images, which can be then iteratively incorporated into the model, by using their redshift estimation and location in the image plane.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Massive Cluster Survey (MACS) has been aimed to create a complete sample of the very X-ray luminous clusters in the Universe, successfully increasing the number of known such clusters to hundreds, particularly at <em>z</em> &gt; 0.3 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b29\" data-open=\"b29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. 2001</a>). From this a complete sample of 12 high-<em>z</em> MACS clusters (<em>z</em> &gt; 0.5) was defined by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. (2007)</a> which have proved very interesting in several follow-up studies including deep X-ray, SZ and <em>HST</em> imaging. Detection of a large-scale filament has been reported in the case of MACS J0717.5+3745 by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling, Barrett &amp; Donovan (2004)</a>, for which many multiply-lensed images have been recently identified by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. (2009a)</a>, revealing this object to be the largest known lens, with an Einstein radius equivalent to 55 arcsec (for a source at <em>z</em>\u223c 2.5). In the case of MACS J1149.5+2223 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b106\" data-open=\"b106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst 2009</a>), a background spiral galaxy at <em>z</em> = 1.49 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b89\" data-open=\"b89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2009</a>) has been shown to be multiply-lensed into several very large images, requiring a very shallow, unrelaxed central mass distribution. Another large multiply-lensed submillimetre source at a redshift of <em>z</em>\u2243 2.9 has been identified in MACS J0454.1\u22120300 (also referred to as MS 0451.6\u22120305; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b93\" data-open=\"b93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Takata et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b7\" data-open=\"b7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Borys et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b3\" data-open=\"b3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Berciano Alba et al. 2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), MACS J0025.4\u22121222 was found to be a \u2018bullet cluster\u2019 like (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brada\u010d et al. 2008b</a>) and other MACS clusters have been recently used for an extensive arc statistics study (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b44\" data-open=\"b44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Horesh et al. 2010</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The X-ray data available for this sample (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. 2007</a>) along with the high-resolution <em>HST</em>/ACS imaging and SZ imaging (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Laroque et al. 2003</a>) make these MACS targets particularly useful for understanding the nature of the most massive clusters. Here we complete a full SL analysis of this 12 cluster sample with the available deep <em>HST</em>/ACS imaging, principally to derive their Einstein radii and also to help constrain the central mass distributions. The effective Einstein radii derived here are the corresponding radii of circles of equivalent areas to those enclosed within the critical curves, or similarly, the radii within which the averaged \u03ba is equal to 1. In addition, this work can also supply detailed magnification maps to help motivate deeper searches for high-<em>z</em> galaxies behind these clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Another major motivation for pursuing accurate lensing-maps is the increased precision of model predictions for cluster-size massive haloes in the standard \u039b cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) model and close variance (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b97\" data-open=\"b97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu &amp; Broadhurst 2008</a>; e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b16\" data-open=\"b16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bullock et al. 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b91\" data-open=\"b91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Spergel et al. 2003</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b92\" data-open=\"b92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b96\" data-open=\"b96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Tegmark et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b42\" data-open=\"b42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hennawi et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b70\" data-open=\"b70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Neto et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b26\" data-open=\"b26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b46\" data-open=\"b46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Keselman, Nusser &amp; Peebles 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b146\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b146\" data-open=\"b146\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Fedeli et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b65\" data-open=\"b65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Meneghetti et al. 2010a</a>). In the standard hierarchical model, large massive bodies are due to collapse recently and thus are not expected to be found in large numbers at high redshifts. On the other hand, the larger volume available with increasing distance means that in practice we cannot expect to reside next to the most massive cluster (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009a</a>). The increasing number of accurately analysed clusters have revealed larger lenses than predicted by the standard \u039bCDM model (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b13\" data-open=\"b13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst &amp; Barkana 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b74\" data-open=\"b74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Puchwein &amp; Hilbert 2009</a>). This discrepancy is empirically supported by the surprisingly concentrated mass profiles measured for such clusters, when combining the inner strong-lensing with the outer weak-lensing signal (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b38\" data-open=\"b38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gavazzi et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b14\" data-open=\"b14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b15\" data-open=\"b15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b58\" data-open=\"b58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b23\" data-open=\"b23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Donnarumma et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b72\" data-open=\"b72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b98\" data-open=\"b98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Umetsu et al. 2010</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b109\" data-open=\"b109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010b</a>), or independently, when using the internal dynamics of cluster members (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b54\" data-open=\"b54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Lemze et al. 2009</a>) and deep X-ray data (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b53\" data-open=\"b53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Lemze et al. 2008</a>). Geometrically, lensing is considered to be optimized at intermediate redshifts, where for a given mass the critical density for lensing is minimal, but this is partly offset by the late hierarchical growth of high-mass systems. This trade-off results in estimates of the amplitude of strong lensing to favour the redshift range <em>z</em> = 0.2\u20130.4. Our recent analysis of two X-ray-selected MACS clusters reveals very large lenses (e.g. MACS J1149.5+2223, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b106\" data-open=\"b106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst 2009</a>; MACS 0717.5+3745, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009a</a>) at high redshift, increasing the tension with \u039bCDM predictions, since large Einstein radius clusters at high <em>z</em> require earlier formation than implied by the standard \u039bCDM model (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b81\" data-open=\"b81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sadeh &amp; Rephaeli 2008</a>). The largest lensing clusters have proven to be excellent targets for accessing the faint early Universe due to their large magnification consistently providing the highest redshift galaxies (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b28\" data-open=\"b28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebbels et al. 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b35\" data-open=\"b35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Franx et al. 1997</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Frye &amp; Broadhurst 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b8\" data-open=\"b8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bouwens et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b49\" data-open=\"b49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b12\" data-open=\"b12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bradley et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b105\" data-open=\"b105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zheng et al. 2009</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The statistics of large Einstein radii provide an important opportunity to test the standard \u039bCDM paradigm, as it probes both the high-mass end of the cluster mass function and central mass distributions of massive clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b71\" data-open=\"b71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford 2009</a>). Increasing numbers of theoretical and observational works have been done recently, deriving Einstein radius distributions of various samples. For example, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b110\" data-open=\"b110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Cypriano et al. (2004)</a> have derived the mass distributions of 24 X-ray-selected Abell clusters via weak-lensing. By fitting to Single Isothermal Sphere (SIS) profiles they obtain a mean Einstein radius of \u223c17 arcsec. More recently, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hoekstra (2007)</a> finds by weak-lensing analysis and SIS fitting a mean Einstein radius of \u223c14 arcsec for a sample of 20 X-ray luminous clusters. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b73\" data-open=\"b73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. (2010)</a> find the mass distribution and Einstein radii for a sample of \u223c30 LoCuSS clusters by fitting the weak-lensing data to CIS profiles, obtaining a mean value of \u223c22 arcsec (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b73\" data-open=\"b73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. 2010</a> and references therein). Note that these values quoted here are calculated from the corresponding tables in these papers and are not necessarily scaled or normalized to certain lens and source redshifts.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Other recent work more relevant to our study summarizes SL analysis for a sample of 20, mostly relaxed <em>undisturbed</em> clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b77\" data-open=\"b77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. 2010b</a>). They find that the Einstein radii are distributed lognormally with a peak at \u03b8<sub>e</sub> = 14.45 arcsec and a corresponding 1.95 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> enclosed mass (within <em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc), and show that the predicted distribution of Einstein radii from \u039bCDM cosmology falls short of the observed Einstein radii by a factor of 2. It has been claimed that much larger Einstein radii can be contemplated only with mass distributions which are highly prolate and aligned along the line of sight (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b21\" data-open=\"b21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Corless &amp; King 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b71\" data-open=\"b71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford 2009</a>; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b42\" data-open=\"b42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hennawi et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b64\" data-open=\"b64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Meneghetti et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b83\" data-open=\"b83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sereno, Jetzer &amp; Lubini 2010</a>). Analysing the 12 X-ray-selected, high-<em>z</em> MACS clusters is important since they are predicted to be massive and should form efficient lenses, whose properties can be then compared to such studies, playing an important role in probing the \u039bCDM scenario.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. In <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2\"></span><a href=\"#ss2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2</a>, we describe the sample and observations; the lensing analysis is described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a>, detailing each cluster separately. Our overall results are presented and discussed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4</a>, followed by a conclusion (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss5\"></span><a href=\"#ss5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 5</a>). Throughout this paper, we adopt the standard cosmology (\u03a9<sub>m0</sub> = 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b0</sub> = 0.7, <em>h</em> = 0.7).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16545157 id=\"16545157\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2>2 THE SAMPLE AND OBSERVATIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The <em>z</em> &gt; 0.5 MACS clusters have been imaged with the Wide Field Channel (WFC) of the ACS installed on <em>HST</em>, mainly in the framework of proposal ID 9722 (PI: Ebeling). This mainly comprises two-filter observations in the <em>F555W</em> and <em>F814W</em> bands, taken during 2003 and 2004 with typical exposure times of \u223c4500 s in each filter. We make use of some other <em>HST</em> data available in the Hubble Legacy Archive (HLA), which we list in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>. In addition, available SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b5\" data-open=\"b5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bertin &amp; Arnouts 1996</a>) photometry catalogues were also downloaded from the HLA and were used to construct colour\u2013magnitude diagrams for identifying the red cluster sequence galaxies belonging to each cluster, as a starting point for each lensing model, as detailed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"16545159\" scrollto-destination=\"16545159\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" data-id=\"t1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Properties of the MACS <em>z</em> &gt; 0.5 sample. The following data (columns 1\u20137) are based on <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. (2007)</a>\u2013 Column 1: cluster name in the MACS survey; Columns 2 and 3: The RA and Dec. of the X-ray centroids (as determined from <em>Chandra</em> ACIS-I data); Column 4: redshifts; Column 5: velocity dispersions, in km s<sup>\u22121</sup>; Column 6: <em>Chandra</em> X-ray luminosities in 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup> quoted for the 0.1\u20132.4 keV band. These luminosities are quoted within <em>r</em><sub>200</sub> and exclude X-ray point sources; Column 7: X-ray temperatures, measured from <em>Chandra</em> data within <em>r</em><sub>1000</sub>, but excluding a central region of 70 kpc radius around the listed X-ray centroid; Column 8: <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. (2007)</a> morphology code \u2013 assessed visually based on the appearance of the X-ray contours and the goodness of the optical/X-ray alignment. The assigned codes (from apparently relaxed to extremely disturbed) are 1 (pronounced cool core, perfect alignment of X-ray peak and single cD galaxy), 2 (good optical/X-ray alignment, concentric contours), 3 (nonconcentric contours, obvious small-scale substructure) and 4 (poor optical/X-ray alignment, multiple peaks, no cD galaxy); errors are estimated as less than 1; and Column 9: ACS bands used here. Note that the clusters MACS J0018.5+1626 and MACS J0454.1\u22120300 are better known from earlier work as Cl0016+1609 and MS 0451.6\u22120305, respectively. For more information, see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. (2007)</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td>MACS\u00a0</td><td>\u03b1 (J2000.0) (<sup>h</sup><sup>m</sup><sup>s</sup>)\u00a0</td><td>\u03b4 (J2000.0) (\u00b0 \u2032 href=\"/view-large/16545159\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" data-id=\"t1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Properties of the MACS <em>z</em> &gt; 0.5 sample. The following data (columns 1\u20137) are based on <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. (2007)</a>\u2013 Column 1: cluster name in the MACS survey; Columns 2 and 3: The RA and Dec. of the X-ray centroids (as determined from <em>Chandra</em> ACIS-I data); Column 4: redshifts; Column 5: velocity dispersions, in km s<sup>\u22121</sup>; Column 6: <em>Chandra</em> X-ray luminosities in 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup> quoted for the 0.1\u20132.4 keV band. These luminosities are quoted within <em>r</em><sub>200</sub> and exclude X-ray point sources; Column 7: X-ray temperatures, measured from <em>Chandra</em> data within <em>r</em><sub>1000</sub>, but excluding a central region of 70 kpc radius around the listed X-ray centroid; Column 8: <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. (2007)</a> morphology code \u2013 assessed visually based on the appearance of the X-ray contours and the goodness of the optical/X-ray alignment. The assigned codes (from apparently relaxed to extremely disturbed) are 1 (pronounced cool core, perfect alignment of X-ray peak and single cD galaxy), 2 (good optical/X-ray alignment, concentric contours), 3 (nonconcentric contours, obvious small-scale substructure) and 4 (poor optical/X-ray alignment, multiple peaks, no cD galaxy); errors are estimated as less than 1; and Column 9: ACS bands used here. Note that the clusters MACS J0018.5+1626 and MACS J0454.1\u22120300 are better known from earlier work as Cl0016+1609 and MS 0451.6\u22120305, respectively. For more information, see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. (2007)</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><td>MACS\u00a0</td><td>\u03b1 (J2000.0) (<sup>h</sup><sup>m</sup><sup>s</sup>)\u00a0</td><td>\u03b4 (J2000.0) (\u00b0 \u2032 29.74\u00a0</td><td>0.546\u00a0</td><td>1660<sup>+120</sup><sub>\u2212130</sub>\u00a0</td><td>24.6 \u00b1 0.3\u00a0</td><td>11.6 \u00b1 0.5\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td><td><em>F555W</em>, <em>F606W</em>, <em>F814W</em>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0744.8+3927\u00a0</td><td>07 44 52.470\u00a0</td><td>+39 27 27.34\u00a0</td><td>0.698\u00a0</td><td>1110<sup>+130</sup><sub>\u2212150</sub>\u00a0</td><td>22.9 \u00b1 0.6\u00a0</td><td>8.1 \u00b1 0.6\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td><em>F555W</em>, <em>F814W</em>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J0911.2+1746\u00a0</td><td>09 11 11.277\u00a0</td><td>+17 46 31.94\u00a0</td><td>0.505\u00a0</td><td>1150<sup>+260</sup><sub>\u2212340</sub>\u00a0</td><td>7.8 \u00b1 0.3\u00a0</td><td>8.8 \u00b1 0.7\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td><td><em>F555W</em>, <em>F814W</em>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1149.5+2223\u00a0</td><td>11 49 35.093\u00a0</td><td>+22 24 10.94\u00a0</td><td>0.544\u00a0</td><td>1840<sup>+120</sup><sub>\u2212170</sub>\u00a0</td><td>17.6 \u00b1 0.4\u00a0</td><td>9.1 \u00b1 0.7\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0</td><td><em>F555W</em>, <em>F814W</em>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J1423.8+2404\u00a0</td><td>14 23 47.663\u00a0</td><td>+24 04 40.14\u00a0</td><td>0.543\u00a0</td><td>1300<sup>+120</sup><sub>\u2212170</sub>\u00a0</td><td>16.5 \u00b1 0.7\u00a0</td><td>7.0 \u00b1 0.8\u00a0</td><td>1\u00a0</td><td><em>F555W</em>, <em>F814W</em>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2129.4\u22120741\u00a0</td><td>21 29 26.214\u00a0</td><td>\u221207 41 26.22\u00a0</td><td>0.589\u00a0</td><td>1400<sup>+170</sup><sub>\u2212200</sub>\u00a0</td><td>15.7 \u00b1 0.4\u00a0</td><td>8.1 \u00b1 0.7\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td><em>F555W</em>, <em>F814W</em>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J2214.9\u22121359\u00a0</td><td>22 14 57.415\u00a0</td><td>\u221214 00 10.78\u00a0</td><td>0.503\u00a0</td><td>1300<sup>+90</sup><sub>\u2212100</sub>\u00a0</td><td>14.1 \u00b1 0.3\u00a0</td><td>8.8 \u00b1 0.7\u00a0</td><td>2\u00a0</td><td><em>F555W</em>, <em>F814W</em>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/16545159\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16545160 id=\"16545160\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3>3 STRONG-LENSING MODELLING AND ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We apply our well-tested approach to lens modelling, which we have applied successfully before to various clusters uncovering unprecedentedly large numbers of multiply-lensed images in Abell 1689, Cl 0024+1654, MACS J1149.5+2223, MACS J0717.5+3745 and MS 1358+6245 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b14\" data-open=\"b14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b106\" data-open=\"b106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009a</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b111\" data-open=\"b111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2010a</a>, respectively). The full details of this approach can be found in these earlier papers. Briefly, the basic assumption adopted is that mass approximately traces light, so that the photometry of the red cluster member galaxies is the starting point for our model. In a recent paper (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b109\" data-open=\"b109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2010b</a>), we analyse Abell 1703 and show that this assumption is well based, by comparison to an assumption-free non-parametric technique (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Liesenborgs, De Rijcke &amp; Dejonghe 2006</a>), which yields a very similar overall mass distribution. In addition, we show that similar to other clusters we have analysed to date, our modelling method has the inherent flexibility to find and reproduce many multiple-images even if initially constrained by only a few obvious systems.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">As mentioned, the starting point of the model are cluster member galaxies, which are identified as lying close to the cluster sequence by the photometry provided in the HLA (in this process sometimes massive foreground galaxies are included as well, scaled down by the relative distance ratio, since they can locally affect nearby images). We then approximate the large-scale distribution of matter by assigning a power-law mass profile to each galaxy, the sum of which is then smoothed. The degree of smoothing (<em>S</em>) and the index of the power law (<em>q</em>) are the most important free parameters determining the mass profile. A worthwhile improvement in fitting the location of the lensed images is generally found by expanding to first order the gravitational potential of the smooth component, equivalent to a coherent shear describing the overall matter ellipticity, where the direction of the shear and its amplitude are free, allowing for some flexibility in the relation between the distribution of DM and the distribution of galaxies, which cannot be expected to trace each other in detail. This freedom also allows the effective centre to slightly shift, as was the case in our analysis of Cl 0024+1654 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009b</a>). The total deflection field, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-mu1.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=4LT9s32eD5cBZr2lC3FtG-w0Lx6-~MQQGXoPsdnG1f7vQ2lcoINy7WKrDCpRExNbcBoItyx3QCpvB-1QCfq9wAdAAxOVQXSdq7tHYnSco8oFVUlLXKVJ5wKjXo2OYZ-Zcw7VDyc6jnn9BGB2tBAxQy8W5vtyR9ueIZh8MCsjYZpEfWbBqh3PUNfBF2LvPWIQKE9wcxETla3OdFy9eiwOEk7DeLJcN0iZM9GdadYE22HbjibWqJx~DLNMXxwpXWW4gyOrxpuEghqCqYJZPuT0IS2IOhZWKIv8khKPo~lxLjZDAwig2tska8~g5O1c~QvG2BsbTfmPnn9QKVuSxnCSeA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-mu1.gif\" />\u2060</span>, consists of the galaxy component, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-mu2.gif\" />\u2060</span>, scaled by a factor <em>K</em><sub>gal</sub>, the cluster DM component, <strong><em>\u03b1</em></strong><sub>DM</sub>(<strong><em>\u03b8</em></strong>), scaled by (1 \u2212<em>K</em><sub>gal</sub>), and the external shear component <strong><em>\u03b1</em></strong><sub>ex</sub>(<strong><em>\u03b8</em></strong>): <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m1\" content-id=\"m1\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-m1.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">1</span></div> where the deflection field at position <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-mu3.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=1d2SgdTvfxJog8F08N3ld648K88VOXB2Lg4wXuhjfkVsMSnD~9weJCVaWJacYZnT~WxCYhD8y~DeKWXGCr0qxeHzrEc0Oj0WOgEVMahq0tPPyKmkhl8-LQela7G8hJle-I84IwMucvRIpt5Ujt64D8kcF0yILb4J9AcWLrOcJ81Qbkc6-s~v-cARMaqLaittkVbfK~ebuOAygCKq3i1TUQuUlTLAVMhpt36enU4O-afzWaAYiEOiETsmKociofaYYM0DuWrP5KOMP7S0XE8vOHHnUyHDHDX14NJApmspNIuX9TLp1dkoHTyuoRcYZPtfe5cRIBHiRzXDnWfNd04F-w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-mu3.gif\" /></span> due to the external shear, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-mu4.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=LYyAozXQ06lcUXUIJRFrLm-9mATpIHOp6acJmOWLlNun-gP3Z3-JfOMJoFBrkKXU-ZYAkr-FdiG96EVWQktpZXOIgWS7cKkSCGasULnSuMGdjgJ06vYQsIJ9lQQcxYfFCJB6lfdpbj0p-PXjmvCsbeLFwodzMWKeYz0upJVzzaoPNAPwNQz2D3xVMxJ742Wzgg-vNpbx9Dd2p7Eh1S55RbvNV-wrAciWTQRr6CO6X-FBn~qnbwYzSXUEAEJZ9gWtDR5slpx1gwQ61MuXiL67SI1z4911NK8QznYAIEaYMpGp3xUiCUny7In6kIHWGCVHoRp8ChQbJF350fpkt7m~iQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-mu4.gif\" />\u2060</span>, is given by<div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m2\" content-id=\"m2\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0410-1939-m2.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-m2.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=46kX9WzzMDLLr626uWv1YKiJCpn97T4B~VrIAQpJ8U6Yg9cjXvQRBOsvmEgqqzGtz5XfDb6jiqQ058JjUv3rB8kWqMDZENNQihAuKfH5Xe0mg~Ua~VuxJR8yVDxCa6coHsuMyEnJ0P9rPwoXLQkQNf49Uz3m18QEBXyjQI-YQj9PDPegjRTapRCP020Lzlqgu1gckgvpgwu5FXIHIHIzVCHnpZUjxQLTzRJr6dxWBNDUf9xXwaOfVKIL7z1KsF-vBZY6fB4tXRkNRa0GuDilcPUdO9e81yDKI4YVjlFr7d9vdDHmXF7KRNXew~WwuOBkYWOfdELYLU4TYvp9K6kmuA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-m2.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">2</span></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m3\" content-id=\"m3\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0410-1939-m3.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-m3.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=e2fPNnxi5BGommqC0WXsY36qIkQoN9xHMRPP-HULelgx2Dk~vY4WlLXqQgenurxfoGCwqtIlcI4syX9mVLTuC-YYYTQYb5Bwn42wErjc90X02ALhVWiUfJUx4CMcI7y9pWKqTQIFYryvgJNfVIXDhgTJwlEBpHkuxdSO9fD9POTZp0uiKfvCG-tluN6t~1Km-9O47nFNyKcMxcjglnyHRUbdbejZHV3bjTnqdlpOB80BE4NZgwIw659Svt5IWMCy14wovdztHS5ejqDONzx7Dte800aH6pR37ystXj9C0h52F0f3RqXbv28ZF3VgNrOoS1jmeHEnc5Z3Tj3XunSi8w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-m3.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">3</span></div> where (\u0394<em>x<sub>m</sub></em>, \u0394<em>y<sub>m</sub></em>) is the displacement vector of the position <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-mu5.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=eaVkzfsirFxQDVmjwbC8nr16aQ5nisLOoJLIR7TBUnHD0c8zcAQbxocwJrHwZZmvYTCS90ebkTo1uVU8IDLiQGCxu9Mhp4Px6SWZ-KPVZXLT94u~ZiwZuUKfRKBKS4wwEJPM6wKexioqKPERQrc6~HYquaSfWSndWpeXNvDi3NJt88uGua96ozErfCFROx6crCrQffQ1ck5f-xL6dAeMTfGVGigMpUOwD-YnoonnTHYZtt31pBCVTNFi8KhWVnwc8cH8D2QfT3VrzNo0AqQHpVHDurLoqQbNhtNUn5y0O~gLrzfTq~Cr5S6754-5fD5QqMwgySL0rqsix-O2BnQgaw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-mu5.gif\" /></span> with respect to a fiducial reference position, which we take as the lower left-hand pixel position (1, 1), and \u03c6<sub>\u03b3</sub> is the position angle of the spin-2 external gravitational shear measured anticlockwise from the <em>x</em>-axis. The normalization of the model and the relative scaling of the smooth DM component versus the galaxy contribution brings the total number of free parameters in the model to six.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Note that since our goal is to find the Einstein radius distribution and the masses within the critical curves, and since many clusters lack multiple-image redshift information, we do not attempt to accurately constrain here the mass profiles of the sample clusters and thus the parameters <em>q</em> and <em>S</em> are relatively irrelevant. Any reasonable values for these parameters yield similar critical curves, Einstein radii and thus also the corresponding masses enclosed within them. This effectively leaves us with four parameters per model, which can be easily constrained by the multiple images incorporated and found here. Still, we have explored also the <em>q</em> and <em>S</em> parameter space for each cluster to verify this. In addition, we showed that in cases where there are too few bands in order to obtain reliable photometric redshifts and where no spectroscopic redshifts are available, a very efficient assumption is that the outer, blue multiple images are at a redshift of <em>z</em>\u223c 2\u20132.5. This assumption is based on previous analysis of many clusters for which the vast majority of the outer blue images are at this redshift range due to the <em>nesting</em> effect by which the critical curve expands for higher redshift objects, yet the redshift of these blue images is limited by the Lyman \u03b1 break to be lower than <em>z</em>\u223c 3. For example, this assumption was proven to be very accurate in MACS J1149.5+2223, where the intermediate-distance blue images we assumed at <em>z</em>\u223c 2 (system 3 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b106\" data-open=\"b106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst 2009</a>) were later spectroscopically found to be at <em>z</em> = 1.89, and our corresponding estimation of the spiral galaxy at <em>z</em>\u2243 1.5 (system 1 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b106\" data-open=\"b106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst 2009</a>) was later verified spectroscopically to be at <em>z</em> = 1.49 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b89\" data-open=\"b89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2009</a>). In addition, in our works on Abell 1689 and Cl 0024+1654, we showed that the same minimum is obtained both when minimizing according to the images location in the image plane, and when minimizing according to the photometric redshifts. This means that in practice also the slope, which generally can be constrained only using redshifts information, can be well approximated by minimizing solely the image-plane rms of the reproduced images, especially if a clear minimum is seen (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009b</a>). Note that here we aim to constrain the critical curves and the mass enclosed within them which are both relatively independent and indifferent to the profile, enabling an accurate measurement also without redshift information, which in turn can be used to approximate the magnification of the lens, since this quantity is profile-dependent.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">First, we use our preliminary models to lens various well detected candidate lensed galaxies back to the source plane using the derived deflection field, and then relens this source plane to predict the detailed appearance and location of additional counter images, which may then be identified in the data by morphology, internal structure and colour. We stress that multiple images found this way must be accurately reproduced by our model and are not simply eyeball \u2018candidates\u2019 requiring redshift verification. Note that due to the volume of this work we do not attempt to exhaust each cluster field finding great numbers of multiple images, and concentrate instead on finding clear examples of multiply-lensed systems to constrain the models and obtain the Einstein radius. The fit is assessed by the rms uncertainty in the image plane: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m4\" content-id=\"m4\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0410-1939-m4.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-m4.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=csVB2PhNJsRHCIATffOAYtBOkDDw37plgXStEZK6IXGYu5KU~nH4U3QJ7qLdegDQ8YSvtMGS4s8JN4Nq8sv7~i~B5Nh9IxhkNi0VGf1diCilaStsw6Xzc0SLEF7wfERQXfoIyzdew-oi2QZq1CDXvBxjKSIdj78EYQ~eUQtA3n4Dr83c5YlFzQRN8mXO5WmIyjz85zcLJ4IU4MgXcQQT7rCO6h5lBf0XSnLndLsO60FIq9iWDA-6Quxsu-f7Qy9UVru~6prPyvPJUAmlCabYc8kqeM8yeoDpruc3ZN6Js4sR5dYivYnxLhMw5H7Wj~MVuA6SW8B6z6YKGDQ1NwjuWQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-m4.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">4</span></div> where <em>x</em>\u2032<sub><em>i</em></sub> and <em>y</em>\u2032<sub><em>i</em></sub> are the locations given by the model, and <em>x<sub>i</sub></em> and <em>y<sub>i</sub></em> are the real images location, and the sum is over all <em>N</em><sub>images</sub> images. The best-fitting solution is obtained by the minimum rms, and the uncertainties are determined by the location of predicted images in the image plane.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Importantly, this image-plane minimization does not suffer from the well known bias involved with source plane minimization, where solutions are biased by minimal scatter towards shallow mass profiles with correspondingly higher magnification. The model is successively refined as additional sets of multiple images are identified and then incorporated to improve the fit, using also their redshifts measurements or estimates for better constraining the mass slope through the cosmological relation of the <em>D</em><sub>ls</sub>/<em>D</em><sub>s</sub> growth (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009b</a>). We detail this procedure for each cluster in the corresponding subsection below, each followed by corresponding figures of the multiple images and the critical curves, and the mass distribution (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1  f24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1  f24\" data-open=\"f1  f24\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 1\u201324</a>). The lensing properties of the sample will be summarised and discussed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4</a> (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f25  f28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f25  f28\" data-open=\"f25  f28\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 25\u201328</a>), and various reproductions of multiple images by our models are shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f29  f35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f29  f35\" data-open=\"f29  f35\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 29\u201335</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"16545166\" scrollto-destination=\"16545166\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=2W-Dma9JXo2f8ArkaATMEbq3hR5FKjsVjzAzuOfkyvYYWiBkeYDEwolh3RNU3CzVE7LCiNFeCBvm36hVBht4WFm4S75VqBDvB4a~eOAimLjuXv6061QwFBo3ift7S9Mn383BpB8q4Ya72BlinBx~okxW-mMAzb4W4gY1pfD~lWF-qsgAtX4oJmJyqjbDc3NzfjUEasdNUyib8QXZOFTIZLll8-ixGJjvh3MnCD4PqrQLNJXpWKusdkxJyol-E9SbDgZj7L7k2h-J9Vq6zcLn1VMHaTvJe2NqaikLoS4h2~8~dd5HQdYBbpnHf3XHK7VWwEzKGg~1PoZGfyzq4m49XA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Galaxy cluster MACS J0018.5+1626 (z = 0.546, also known as Cl 0016+1609, or MS 0016) imaged with Hubble/ACS F606W, F775W and F850LP bands. The blue curve overlaid shows the tangential critical curve corresponding to the distance of system 1 at an estimated redshift of z\u223c 1.5, and which passes through the close triplet of lensed arcs in this system. The larger critical curve overlaid in white corresponds to the larger source distance estimated as z\u223c 2\u20132.5, passing through the close pairs of the candidate images of systems 2 and 3. This critical curve encloses a large lensed region, with an equivalent Einstein radius of \u223c150 kpc at the redshift of the cluster. Note that our model predicts tiny images of pairs 2.1/2.2 and 3.1/3.2 at the other side of the cluster, which we are not able to securely detect due to poor depth and lack of colour range.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16545166/mnras0410-1939-f1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16545166\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/mnras0410-1939-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&Signature=ju41QdP198LpzREMvuz8BJ5Gy6KiUyTIfDdyb1vTFygULPsEAqfeUraFKraeQV0lUmqEetZuFtCqH-kRjuvnAbKEVwA~heT05wGDRfNsVHxJ2EtUXCX9OBjF9~UpO0BJlyfp9u90CJgGR9-CnijtZMszsU~AVtsh7WQ4foGHmmvEFoNGvM3q4pQly6RrWzX2qfE4UqdofB-1L72gGO9St6RBar7d23cKbf8fZ3U1zIe17WoEoOVhatsDJhsMQJnzz5OnJWl1sG7ngaZen0KmG5NTy-2xuewxmaVVcwKTNtAPgpBn3UszonXqosPkmF38Wci29-MPyzzwjkDz3NsQ4Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16545166&ar=963929&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy cluster MACS J0018.5+1626 (<em>z</em> = 0.546, also known as Cl 0016+1609, or MS 0016) imaged with <em>Hubble</em>/ACS <em>F606W</em>, <em>F775W</em> and <em>F850LP</em> bands. The larger critical curves overlaid in white correspond to a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2\u20132.5, passing through the close pair of images 4.1 and 4.2.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"16545171\" scrollto-destination=\"16545171\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=OvmsPjl8JNkUHsVPZ4x9S5H4sj4jAiMRjTxmJbQ-xN4-AhG3Pvzfnh7eFxqpvq6RdA2pm5SmvuuXFormDbwd5PIz7y7uQxIx23nZNC7PLr3WEY5rS9G5ttpsFPt19b0BEhZNjcBvE2B8FG5BjfD84AIW8tkGhGx6csWNoa2vfXafu8QVjQbwWUq8WRiJstKOptpQcZDx9hyiNJ2iHLHnOhpEL5TnGiY73SU5vQHnGTDqIH1owu6Y1KGeUo4jdrp5iFQBb6dHvMJ3cCaB2sureyu6TZfCw9RiQlQ~-wHZj9SwcGRcv4g57kIAYHAljsxZAK1HWzuGLhh0OeNnALOPSg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"2D surface mass distribution (\u03ba), in units of the critical density, of MACS J0257.1\u22122325. The 34 multiply-lensed images identified by our model are numbered here. The white curve overlaid shows the tangential critical curve corresponding to the distance of system 1 at an estimated redshift of z\u223c 2\u20132.5, and which passes through several close pairs of lensed images in this system. The larger critical curve overlaid in red corresponds to the larger source distance for the red dropout galaxy number 5, at the estimated photometric redshift of z\u223c 3.5\u20134. This large tangential critical curve encloses a very large lensed region equivalent to \u223c400 kpc in radius at the redshift of the cluster. Figure was originally published in Zitrin et al. (2009a).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16545176/mnras0410-1939-f11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16545176\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/mnras0410-1939-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&Signature=KImDc18ba-zFjd8O2YSpIQa7hGuZ-bnfvIiR6vM9GwlPQYezuO2GLh2YsPZanHcHmsb2xYtoUA2DRyPv-kuSG8HqY0NXdRYrJ-97g~bmYrbbLKuqckVmBYnlcQdj6D5UpFEwJzFM2uXKdt~u-MoOYCFBgy6LRXtNYWuky9dyVYHSKe18MUS~YnbFvihhScKqxUwUGW8VX5pVadxmIGYDsuFYYz~CCEhDZTIX219F6Lhlk1KTP~aTOghd3s2algu8pGC5IgkkiGLeWnzf9b41WRNJ2lJNhzi2eGY5RWd1ylqCyDPl4UGrubsm4G0KAmCEPX3wdfM1ucFvs7SK7g8NBg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16545176&ar=963929&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy cluster MACS J0717.5+3745 (<em>z</em> = 0.546) imaged with <em>Hubble</em>/ACS <em>F555W</em>, <em>F606W</em>, and <em>F814W</em> bands. The 34 multiply-lensed images identified by our model are numbered here. The white curve overlaid shows the tangential critical curve corresponding to the distance of system 1 at an estimated redshift of <em>z</em>\u223c 2\u20132.5, and which passes through several close pairs of lensed images in this system. The larger critical curve overlaid in red corresponds to the larger source distance for the red dropout galaxy number 5, at the estimated photometric redshift of <em>z</em>\u223c 3.5\u20134. This large tangential critical curve encloses a very large lensed region equivalent to \u223c400 kpc in radius at the redshift of the cluster. Figure was originally published in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. (2009a)</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=4vB06qJz18Qn7K7f~0CMpZuZhLL-pitWnkruXpTCsf0AEgDpq9PAilDxvaXCxDkS2egPZtGGz3LguvwpXNG5l6UbUWbdBVG6DDZL4y-wsLrP97gHxumm30Fpg7VmJoneuIpjrJwULIxbiNjVsInO65fJLHVn9VjBsy~wsgZBQ~GH8gBdP8lHrQVgv8PUXa~900jGUWqEzEFS2v8UL1wvhggb-Y45JUMoSKU3QRjuS4QgqSmY~8X5x2iBfr2xzVAlWPxR6OKauZJ0tFALmluolCP4ensZYnmfzZR7g8cWgyFfT-rMFAuBrgF~hvVOf5rfM5-4qhjOTG1wZ5s4GIO0Tw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Galaxy cluster MACS J0717.5+3745 (z = 0.546) imaged with Hubble/ACS F555W, F606W, and F814W bands. The 34 multiply-lensed images identified by our model are numbered here. The white curve overlaid shows the tangential critical curve corresponding to the distance of system 1 at an estimated redshift of z\u223c 2\u20132.5, and which passes through several close pairs of lensed images in this system. The larger critical curve overlaid in red corresponds to the larger source distance for the red dropout galaxy number 5, at the estimated photometric redshift of z\u223c 3.5\u20134. This large tangential critical curve encloses a very large lensed region equivalent to \u223c400 kpc in radius at the redshift of the cluster. Figure was originally published in Zitrin et al. (2009a).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16545176/mnras0410-1939-f11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16545176\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/mnras0410-1939-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&Signature=KImDc18ba-zFjd8O2YSpIQa7hGuZ-bnfvIiR6vM9GwlPQYezuO2GLh2YsPZanHcHmsb2xYtoUA2DRyPv-kuSG8HqY0NXdRYrJ-97g~bmYrbbLKuqckVmBYnlcQdj6D5UpFEwJzFM2uXKdt~u-MoOYCFBgy6LRXtNYWuky9dyVYHSKe18MUS~YnbFvihhScKqxUwUGW8VX5pVadxmIGYDsuFYYz~CCEhDZTIX219F6Lhlk1KTP~aTOghd3s2algu8pGC5IgkkiGLeWnzf9b41WRNJ2lJNhzi2eGY5RWd1ylqCyDPl4UGrubsm4G0KAmCEPX3wdfM1ucFvs7SK7g8NBg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16545176&ar=963929&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy cluster MACS J0717.5+3745 (<em>z</em> = 0.546) imaged with <em>Hubble</em>/ACS <em>F555W</em>, <em>F606W</em>, and <em>F814W</em> bands. The 34 multiply-lensed images identified by our model are numbered here. The white curve overlaid shows the tangential critical curve corresponding to the distance of system 1 at an estimated redshift of <em>z</em>\u223c 2\u20132.5, and which passes through several close pairs of lensed images in this system. The larger critical curve overlaid in red corresponds to the larger source distance for the red dropout galaxy number 5, at the estimated photometric redshift of <em>z</em>\u223c 3.5\u20134. This large tangential critical curve encloses a very large lensed region equivalent to \u223c400 kpc in radius at the redshift of the cluster. Figure was originally published in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. (2009a)</a>.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"16545177\" scrollto-destination=\"16545177\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-f12.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=x-hVFs6XrLVfv~e~1kgSgUK8Bg8ULvaqY0rcJKa82K2xV~Ye9iBZbLrxgaa7DZvoEkmwWmxObfru8VXsMqGvMFCV8CvG6ePh5aMCIyBNKIaZPTRznXN~q75Pe5mwYcr-RFhC0H2Pk0n1hN52H7zcSBDnDYsA4JSHZe68ymtTeZpvkC98CwpjQBWAhn7N6W-ZM6u-O40kdFCVKL2Z78afHL1ySxtfFcElFYMfLrntJSCPP2WQV6byhor6wCIeG1-HS9ECN2jlvSEtSVRC8z5YLWdA0wQTEekx9FwKBO4AWZKdOeIzaYDYXwcRKNpWjvIcH~Kjte4znQUDDA~7~k74~Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"2D surface mass distribution (\u03ba), in units of the critical density, of the inner central region of MACS J0717.5+3745. Axes are in ACS pixels (0.05 arcsec pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>), and a 20-arcsec scale bar is overplotted.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"16545182\" scrollto-destination=\"16545182\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f17\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 17</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-f17.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=tfwk-4kMMoNDOF2naNcVBq-J7Hr7Rusg6fItcH4FKxKfyCUsF4wWthTwS8tkipDyJoDbz9Z7pYhFmLU~Ih92cjYO0x8qy0HLZwMJ7DCAbxWkDmk1jjoGpyX5p~OcOcc29WCMiRRWpgeRfwJixGQ5v6QNAst4D8EQeDtcXJJHqmkFoFM0fjOrQSF9TfatLmmRpCHa0yrzWU9VLkHJkiY0IH607HllrbnQhD1tdAQSCVSH-9onIXal9ZS506~GHvW00~yY0-VmXwH7nwM0GsVhZxADxLXJIq57eGSx8raYUeWTyCNAqKuquLxMONhKIvqZaIjDx3qoofj6fprjrfhboQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Large-scale view of the multiply-lensed galaxies identified by our model in MACS J1149.5+2223 (z = 0.544). In addition to the large spiral galaxy system 1, many other fainter sets of multiply lensed galaxies are uncovered by our model. The white curve overlaid shows the tangential critical curve corresponding to the lensing distance of system 1. The larger critical curve overlaid in blue corresponds to the average distance of the fainter systems, passing through close pairs of lensed images in systems 2 and 3. This large-scale elongated \u2018Einstein ring\u2019 encloses a very large critically lensed region equivalent to 170 kpc in radius. For this cluster, 1 arcsec corresponds to 6.4 kpc, with the standard cosmology. Figure was originally published in Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst (2009).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f17.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/16545182/mnras0410-1939-f17.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f17.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"16545182\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/mnras0410-1939-f17.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&Signature=O4ASfKCZglByxrJfhMKmXS9J3nLo7N7k83qkAHE~hc2Mvif-g0hB3Q2lT9ZxrXkWOQ-IhlCQu5iXTSeV4HQyIWqbURfXsUUPYa4iF~UkvlqbBr04m86z3~mldIpj6vVLlzdKaoJXngErlEPV3xGXt8hfcbHNujTiz1yXRxUZNkfAD6wXs7A84U6cYsYrDE7Idi5pnMDPKtmLR5ryd1Fygtz9qnGk8rIT2irgcI0P8xxHXClH0crnLhwKolQQ0wBGmS4bEK2TzJt1nxWQOGBrFAQEDdA9V5AOOxUotLVxp71OZNIumopB~mdg8HkKYcOD6ZfjVhSQ75YJVOfGS~ZKgw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=16545182&ar=963929&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-f17.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Large-scale view of the multiply-lensed galaxies identified by our model in MACS J1149.5+2223 (<em>z</em> = 0.544). In addition to the large spiral galaxy system 1, many other fainter sets of multiply lensed galaxies are uncovered by our model. The white curve overlaid shows the tangential critical curve corresponding to the lensing distance of system 1. The larger critical curve overlaid in blue corresponds to the average distance of the fainter systems, passing through close pairs of lensed images in systems 2 and 3. This large-scale elongated \u2018Einstein ring\u2019 encloses a very large critically lensed region equivalent to 170 kpc in radius. For this cluster, 1 arcsec corresponds to 6.4 kpc, with the standard cosmology. Figure was originally published in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b106\" data-open=\"b106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst (2009)</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f17\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 17</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-f17.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=tfwk-4kMMoNDOF2naNcVBq-J7Hr7Rusg6fItcH4FKxKfyCUsF4wWthTwS8tkipDyJoDbz9Z7pYhFmLU~Ih92cjYO0x8qy0HLZwMJ7DCAbxWkDmk1jjoGpyX5p~OcOcc29WCMiRRWpgeRfwJixGQ5v6QNAst4D8EQeDtcXJJHqmkFoFM0fjOrQSF9TfatLmmRpCHa0yrzWU9VLkHJkiY0IH607HllrbnQhD1tdAQSCVSH-9onIXal9ZS506~GHvW00~yY0-VmXwH7nwM0GsVhZxADxLXJIq57eGSx8raYUeWTyCNAqKuquLxMONhKIvqZaIjDx3qoofj6fprjrfhboQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Large-scale view of the multiply-lensed galaxies identified by our model in MACS J1149.5+2223 (z = 0.544). In addition to the large spiral galaxy system 1, many other fainter sets of multiply lensed galaxies are uncovered by our model. The white curve overlaid shows the tangential critical curve corresponding to the lensing distance of system 1. The larger critical curve overlaid in blue corresponds to the average distance of the fainter systems, passing through close pairs of lensed images in systems 2 and 3. The white curve overlaid shows the tangential critical curve corresponding to the lensing distance of system 1. This large-scale elongated \u2018Einstein ring\u2019 encloses a very large critically lensed region equivalent to 170 kpc in radius. (2010) to be at zs = 2.84 and system 2 was spectroscopically measured by them to be at zs = 1.78. The multiple images used in our model are marked on the image. System 1 was spectroscopically measured by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. (2010)</a> to be at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 2.84 and system 2 was spectroscopically measured by them to be at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 1.78. The multiple images used in our model are marked on the image. System 1 was spectroscopically measured by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. (2010)</a> to be at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 2.84 and system 2 was spectroscopically measured by them to be at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 1.78. On the image, we overlay the critical curves for a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2, enclosing a critical area with equivalent Einstein radius of \u223c130 kpc at the cluster redshift.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"16545185\" scrollto-destination=\"16545185\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f20\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 20</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-f20.jpeg?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=tZDYe~p3FXCzcmkCnm5Kf64pAKiCtFiFdWkjzCXwddeEYJYQORIjL0qvnZK1HeB8r1n1R-fJZwBPTcPybZ3tB12YDNUQE-c7TPNbH2yTBmY1VGewxpsR09Di6cHJmOphZLBb4WvlqXoMjl2jJdzaSvVIC~GzhfyJJyrDAv5gP43pqBGBLPwAoM4ezLBVmneTouZ05sRAM~cpbtkQ9PHqGx3GhtCJc75U40AggFijW7zwTW9jtnxQHXtLippDgfEwI8QLl8sQRYTrerphnruE-CzeTq6sCltEAZHE6Jft60qdtA47w8KiZKmGXKQ5a~8k5zxd-DyhxvcnAWSXpWOQYA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"2D surface mass distribution (\u03ba), in units of the critical density, of MACS J1423.8+2404.
