J2214.9\u22121359 by our model by delensing image 1.1 into the source plane and relensing the source-plane pixels on to the image plane to accurately form the other images.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545202 id=\"16545202\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1>3.1 MACS J0018.5+1626</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The galaxy cluster MACS J0018.5+1626 (<em>z</em> = 0.546, also known as Cl 0016+1609, or MS 0016) has been subject to extensive study, mainly due to its high X-ray luminosity, strong SZ effect, and high redshift (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b24\" data-open=\"b24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dressler &amp; Gunn 1992</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b25\" data-open=\"b25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Dressler et al. 1999</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b60\" data-open=\"b60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Luppino et al. 1999</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b33\" data-open=\"b33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ellis &amp; Jones 2002</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Clowe et al. 2000</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Clowe, Luppino &amp; Kaiser 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Laroque et al. 2003</a>), setting an example of a rich distant cluster (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b101\" data-open=\"b101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Worrall &amp; Birkinshaw 2003</a>, and references therein). It has been established that this cluster is the major part of a large-scale filamentary structure (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b101\" data-open=\"b101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Worrall &amp; Birkinshaw 2003</a>, and references therein; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b94\" data-open=\"b94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Tanaka et al. 2007</a>). This fact and the prominent X-ray emission imply a high cluster mass, which should be manifested in multiply-lensed systems spread throughout the field. However, due to lower quality optical data and the complexity of its structure, no multiply-lensed systems were found in MACS J0018.5+1626 up to date. Only one strongly lensed arc was referred to before in this cluster (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b52\" data-open=\"b52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Lavery 1996</a>), yet neither spectroscopic redshift nor counter-images were introduced. We begin our analysis by constructing an initial model in the method described above (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a>), where as a starting point we insert averaged values to the various parameters, since no system is known a priori to constrain the fit. We then notice the similar colours and symmetry of the images of systems 1\u20133. After verifying that the reproduction of these systems is physically likely in the context of our model, we use these systems to fully constrain the model and derive the critical curves (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>), their corresponding Einstein radius (\u03b8<sub>e</sub> = 28 \u00b1 2 arcsec for a source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2; systems 2 and 3) and the mass enclosed within them [(1.46 \u00b1 0.1) \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>] (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 1</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f2\" data-open=\"f2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> for more information). Accordingly, the estimated redshift of system 1 is <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 1.5.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">There are various other mass estimates for this cluster, mainly from weak-lensing analyses. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b87\" data-open=\"b87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. (1997)</a> quote values of \u223c2.9 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> and \u223c1.87 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> within 200 kpc (depending on the method, see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b86\" data-open=\"b86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. 1995</a>) and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hoekstra (2007)</a> quotes a value of \u223c7.9 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> within 500 kpc, all in general accordance with our measurement. The Einstein radius for this cluster was also mentioned before. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hoekstra (2007)</a> quotes \u223c9 arcsec from an SIS model fit to the tangential distortion from 0.25 to 1.5<em>h</em><sup>\u22121</sup> Mpc, while <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b99\" data-open=\"b99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Williams, Navarro &amp; Bartelmann (1999)</a> quote 25 arcsec according to the arc discussed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b52\" data-open=\"b52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Lavery (1996)</a>, in accordance with our estimation. The reference centre of our analysis is fixed near the centre of the <em>F775W</em> (program ID 10493) ACS frame at RA =<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-mu6.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=e1KxfaCXLeacKr-fHzJZnDB3yMsPwcwpMDXNH-TNCQ4v9PUMjhISbz8IJzfvhCOCi2FxyMRsICkmg1TahuFWCNqWewAnY9DaGJZG9bjBo6pamGilRGqG2ICaVR3r2pAkLgQOfPvfk0B4f7g7r7BxRBekI9J6p1XUrl~shRIjv4XoBuKQRj8JD87N15DbyUZd89FseZLqpE5UuvJ0C6MfnFMBYe-4Mczp-aOV3XUj11gAAWot0qfcezFowQpA6t~U97yPtD5NxGWU41LuGJfWP1PLA1ldQRfcw7KwPW4kKq3hLRFx5T5XWgoBp2jR12gKOCbaFQHVXIJqnE3cA4KsTA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-mu6.gif\" />\u2060</span>, Dec. =+16\u00b026\u203214\u2033.95 (J2000.0), where 1 arcsec corresponds to 6.42 kpc at the redshift of this cluster.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545205 id=\"16545205\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-2>3.2 MACS J0025.4\u22121222</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The galaxy cluster MACS J0025.4\u22121222 (<em>z</em> = 0.584) and its merging properties were recently analysed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brada\u010d et al. (2008b)</a>, which found multiply-lensed images of four background galaxies, and obtained spectroscopic redshifts for a pair of them and photometric redshifts for the other two systems: system A+B (system 1 here) at <em>z</em><sub>spec</sub> = 2.38, system C (system 2 here) at <em>z</em><sub>phot</sub> = 1<sup>+0.5</sup><sub>\u22120.2</sub>, and system D (system 3 here) at <em>z</em><sub>phot</sub> = 2.8<sup>+0.4</sup><sub>\u22121.8</sub>. We use systems 1 and 2 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>) and one more uncovered arc (system 4 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>; <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 1.9) to derive the corresponding Einstein radius (\u03b8<sub>e</sub> = 30 \u00b1 2 arcsec for <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2.38) and the mass enclosed within it (2.42<sup>+0.10</sup><sub>\u22120.13</sub>\u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>), in excellent agreement with the result of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brada\u010d et al.</a> (2008b; \u22432.5 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>, within 300 kpc centred on the SE BCG). In addition, we find that system A in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brada\u010d et al.</a> (2008b; system 1 here) also includes an additional arc on the other side of the BCG, as shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a> (arc 1.2), which our model reproduces very accurately (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f30\" data-open=\"f30\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 30</a>). The reference centre of our analysis is fixed near the centre of the ACS frame at RA =<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-mu7.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=Xj6G6vHlh886y6jW7lx9Nb91BXaaJAthtKRolnsJUr0iW7j7RCnz-AyN8~AgcV3wo6mnDdkWMrPsObU4BKi3zUhqrc0nbq3Q5J66WM7uf5drEN33ECu-qeblrloHU1ksmMue4Xh-LbsqEDoj-a3dETUPcRf~ghFKEHboVz3lSPvCiuIWAfOzq0~97k~b~oSildF4WFRJ9Q~69GaiURzxN0G1OEvnpyUxOJKGFGO4Fu4WBpp905bDmn2~bE1y8R9tYKjEIFPH90bobZ4-QjyZss2f76zx2MlelORoHfCEV~U-WgV8p5jaturkrhJAPfDnhrBbh64rxtxiINZ~bgTlTw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-mu7.gif\" />\u2060</span>, Dec. =\u221212\u00b022\u203252\u2033.89 (J2000.0), where 1 arcsec corresponds to 6.64 kpc at the redshift of this cluster.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545207 id=\"16545207\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-3>3.3 MACS J0257.1\u22122325</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the galaxy cluster MACS J0257.1\u22122325 (<em>z</em> = 0.505), various arcs are seen, from which we use 13 multiply-lensed images, belonging to approximately seven background distant galaxies, in the redshift range <em>z</em>\u223c 1 to <em>z</em>\u223c 4 to fully constrain the model. The reference centre of our analysis is fixed near the centre of the ACS frame at RA =<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-mu8.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=AxbjL6~ZzwcckJpss2MZ~jMjb6ae5SB9hbL7AVfU2tdzubdliL-7822NkKcOOFY4Qw5C1kPnYqlvc1-RF7oMCfTKe3j6SCWDV9Rpvm~xZ6ExWXLR-gS-bgBcOW-NNZMvsrlnk8JvwrirsWux9v1lK59qd3pzwQ6dF94ZpNawbLfb0kxxyI3qQQJOKTlrORV~oBAJuPhNRNy6TbqsrVNZ9NVhoc9c7ODjPLJ5zHA8vt3n5QZihNHLbcsskhVUutktX7gID-5dmQcE8fOwPPdR948DlXxLYeon0qHVWBTmNxOr0-PHRjwhAxdcZkRw3SGbfA3jPASRvN8ECSeffjNtDg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-mu8.gif\" />\u2060</span>, Dec. =\u221223\u00b026\u203202.\u203388 (J2000.0), where 1 arcsec corresponds to 6.17 kpc at the redshift of this cluster. This cluster was not analysed before and we did not find any arc redshift information. We assume a redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2\u20132.5 for the faint distant blue images (system 4 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>) according to which the spectacular images next to the cD galaxy (system 1; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f31\" data-open=\"f31\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 31</a>) are at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 1, the blue images of systems 2 and 3 are at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 1.5\u20132 and the red drop-out candidates are at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 3.5\u20134 (system 5) helping to constrain the fit. We find that the critical curves (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>) have an equivalent Einstein radius of 39 \u00b1 2 arcsec (for <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2) and enclose a mass of 3.35<sup>+0.58</sup><sub>\u22120.10</sub>\u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545209 id=\"16545209\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-4>3.4 MACS J0454.1\u22120300</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The galaxy cluster MACS J0454.1\u22120300 (<em>z</em> = 0.538, also known as MS 0451.6\u22120305) has been subject to extensive study due to its high X-ray luminosity, strong SZ effect, and high redshift (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b32\" data-open=\"b32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ellingson et al. 1998</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b69\" data-open=\"b69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Molnar et al. 2002</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Laroque et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b39\" data-open=\"b39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Geach et al. 2006</a>), and is known to host various lensed submillimetre sources with radio counterparts (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b93\" data-open=\"b93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Takata et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b7\" data-open=\"b7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Borys et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b3\" data-open=\"b3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Berciano Alba et al. 2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), which we incorporate in our analysis below. Previous strong-lensing models of this cluster were introduced by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b7\" data-open=\"b7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Borys et al. (2004)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Berciano Alba et al. (2010)</a> with similar symmetry as our model. We fully constrain our model with the arcs and their redshift information listed in these papers (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f7\" data-open=\"f7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 7</a> here), from which we derive an effective Einstein radius of 19 \u00b1 2 arcsec for a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 2.9 (system 1 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f7\" data-open=\"f7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 7</a>) and a mass of 0.82<sup>+0.03</sup><sub>\u22120.01</sub>\u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> enclosed within this critical curve. For a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2, we correspondingly get an effective Einstein radius of 13 \u00b1 2 arcsec, and a mass of 0.41<sup>+0.03</sup><sub>\u22120.01</sub>\u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> enclosed within the critical curve (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f7\" data-open=\"f7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 7</a>). <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Berciano Alba et al. (2010)</a> quote a mass of 1.73 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> within 30 arcsec of the cluster centre. Our model yields 1.8 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> within 30 arcsec of the cluster centre, in full agreement. In our modelling process, we find two other systems of multiply-lensed images. The first (system 3) is a triplet of faint arcs next to the core, at an estimated redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 1.5\u20132. The second system (number 4) consists of 4 bright images, all have prominent emission in the <em>K</em>\u2032 band (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b93\" data-open=\"b93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Takata et al. 2003</a>), corresponding to a redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u2243 2.9 similar to system 1 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f7\" data-open=\"f7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 7</a> for more details). The reference centre of our analysis is fixed near the centre of the <em>F555W</em> (proposal ID 9722) ACS frame at RA =<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-mu9.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=Au0GEqjwdk39cp8uXCtV8r5BbwzBudKPhzzSvMpUt9Z2N-PJoqJIuPk4UT0T6easuioK-thCHrwBa5kQdqwuEAi3E3IoR6MtpkOuG9mBv12p0vIL9MIBIG16U6vse-eRkZoLXRJsuSGHUb1l~KTLhyBj-Nokgmh5as~4OKvKMJft35t5ZXNweq~JovWxtub5-AymzRQD9VDnMmrvqWZv-IMH13MAPsw~R0-OF83o~xtbpsW3vBOZ0yAwJ1F4vw0f83skMdcIv7JCYIp4smsyEDnPOkV1UwIjM9XWCxs3r8ISTscr8S26UtMvwayZTZiak64TI8OyDccsgcuxYDjV-Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-mu9.gif\" />\u2060</span>, Dec. =\u221203\u00b001\u203203.\u203302 (J2000.0), where 1 arcsec corresponds to 6.37 kpc at the redshift of this cluster.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545211 id=\"16545211\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-5>3.5 MACS J0647.7+7015</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the galaxy cluster MACS J0647.7+7015 (<em>z</em> = 0.591), we note a remarkable blue background system lensed six times, where each lensed image is a quartet of arcs, spread across the image and between the BCGs. Additional blue faint images between images 1.5 and 1.6 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f9\" data-open=\"f9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 9</a>) may also be related to this system. We did not find any record of past analysis nor redshift information and we assume the redshift of this system to be <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2 corresponding to an equivalent Einstein radius of 28 \u00b1 2 arcsec enclosing a mass of (2.07 \u00b1 0.10) \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. This also corresponds to the higher redshift assumed for system 2, which is estimated to be a drop-out galaxy at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 3.5, helping us to constrain the fit (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f9\" data-open=\"f9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 9</a> for more details). The reference centre of our analysis is fixed between the two cD galaxies at RA =<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-mu10.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=D3d3~tpxw8z~R7rVLdi502J-ShFxrI2asLtbSfvRclrZXjsr70XPr8dDyQuU5dazKeVHZ5IaK5auGDFCHBGmJOcKgrizOnG3BHlG4a0DFHtaSgohMxFsoD-YzI0yEESgFetX6r~ObmSxOx-z-lSpzEj8-8f8e5y8~979Qx-XxG9GB0G~D2V7WcwduA~OEJ1Enih~-aCVECOoAbCFRxIlui76PKnVBXBeLZCau5RL7c3ghBPFigqARkXXh0CcexdPRBnIKOj6vr8HiwWRv2UDn2u0vErur5qSAA6ZjFSueFKOTAlLhTZXmBrMROr9JL32QlvcatOP2jUO02hbdqHbCg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-mu10.gif\" />\u2060</span>, Dec. =+70\u00b014\u203255\u2033.37 (J2000.0), where 1 arcsec corresponds to 6.67 kpc at the redshift of this cluster.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545213 id=\"16545213\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-6>3.6 MACS J0717.5+3745</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The galaxy cluster MACS J0717.5+3745 (<em>z</em> = 0.55) was analysed recently by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. (2009a)</a>. This very X-ray luminous cluster is the denser north-western region of the large-scale filament found by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. (2004)</a> and it is the largest known lens, with an equivalent Einstein radius of 55 arcsec and a mass of (7.4 \u00b1 0.5) \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. 13 multiply-lensed systems were used to constrain the fit as seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f11\" data-open=\"f11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 11</a> taken from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. (2009a)</a>. Due to its very large critical area, this cluster is a great target for finding high-<em>z</em> objects, and has been recently proposed for uncovering early stars (or \u2018dark stars\u2019, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b102\" data-open=\"b102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zackrisson et al. 2010</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545215 id=\"16545215\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-7>3.7 MACS J0744.8+3927</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The luminous X-ray cluster MACS J0744.8+3927 (<em>z</em> = 0.698) is the highest-<em>z</em> cluster of this sample, comprising several obvious close pairs of multiply-lensed galaxies which are immediately visible throughout the frame, with which we begin our modelling process (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f13\" data-open=\"f13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 13</a>). Systems 2 and 4 are likely drop-outs and we estimate their redshift as <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 3.5 which helps to constrain our model. These systems correspond to similar lensing distance ratios thus basing this assumption. We did not find record of past analysis yet recently a spectroscopic redshift of a resolved galaxy behind this cluster was published (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b45\" data-open=\"b45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jones et al. 2010</a>; <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 2.21, marked as \u2018S1\u2019 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f13\" data-open=\"f13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 13</a> here). Unfortunately, no counter images were reported. As can be seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f13\" data-open=\"f13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 13</a>, this arc lies within the critical curve for a source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u2243 2.2 according to our model, and therefore should be multiply-lensed and we mark other possible counter images of this galaxy. Another option, which would favour a steeper model, is that the three clumps seen in this arc are counter images of the same galaxy, though we find this option to be less probable according to the velocity map presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b45\" data-open=\"b45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jones et al. (2010)</a>, which shows that the three clumps have different velocities. In addition, another less probable case is that the critical curve for a source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u2243 2.2 is much smaller, though this does not agree with the other assumed redshifts for the outer blue arcs (e.g. system 1), which are not likely be at a higher redshift than <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 3 since they are closer to the cluster centre than system 2 but following the same symmetry, yet clearly seen in the <em>F555W</em> band. Deeper imaging in more passbands will help to uniquely solve the strong lensing in this cluster. We derive an equivalent Einstein radius of 31 \u00b1 2 arcsec for a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u2243 2.2, enclosing a mass of (3.1 \u00b1 0.1) \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. The reference centre of our analysis is fixed on the cD galaxy at RA =<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-mu11.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=NmoOILDVd1PuZBhzghfvfB22yYeBsHxEvtBY5lW~YpA38vo7mYbXqFMPahN6asg1KfnYwIGTcQJnd3OEmmtoT2xymEnEUyzHEFtZu9woGZnIwcMLucdAhfOhSteaNo2PlYJmTeRW8ZDus7g4hUSHYjD8BcQHgsE11YwXfDLiVJqIMyyNZLt-Fp11sW53bpPWDvHnjjnyDxUbqsCd2CwmdjajfYaYQVOoB8AitlBzDoFbSiqCFdqt1eYolyCkHtF~qKbieiRGQ0gdEqBArLkOLjHOCWBRN-tc2uOE3bT4wYPBmdTDEVBIgrPQ9pRGyjt2~e3jgVY63Ax7Awh---mk9g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-mu11.gif\" />\u2060</span>, Dec. =+39\u00b027\u203226\u2033.50 (J2000.0), where 1 arcsec corresponds to 7.17 kpc at the redshift of this cluster.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545217 id=\"16545217\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-8>3.8 MACS J0911.2+1746</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the galaxy cluster MACS J0911.2+1746 (<em>z</em> = 0.505) not many prominent arcs are seen, in agreement with the small critical area we derived (\u03b8<sub>e</sub> = 11<sup>+3</sup><sub>\u22121</sub> arcsec, for a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2). We found no record of previous SL analysis of this cluster nor arcs redshift information. Only a few arcs are seen throughout the frame, from which we are able to match seven multiply-lensed images which are iteratively incorporated into the model, belonging to three distant galaxies. Two of these galaxies (systems 1 and 2) are to our estimation at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2. We find that the mass enclosed within the critical curves (for a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2) is 0.28<sup>+0.02</sup><sub>\u22120.01</sub>\u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. This critical curve and the enclosed mass are both the smallest of the current sample (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f15\" data-open=\"f15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 15</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f16\" data-open=\"f16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">16</a> for more details). The reference centre of our analysis is fixed near the centre of the ACS frame at RA =<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-mu12.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=Z~y4-ZayjqnsNH2fm1bq4ifHa1FGlIj2NLAteP27rIPJhwM5rEOmLUUYtIV63LIDzIZ-46lxojvTVtvcE0elbi4nQHrGKk-K03UgDYZnJ-mXYqHQsz3dL53F9hF~1q1XBy5yIN-fxkS~iPj2UVujFgLwN5v0PQMxhg7hz8-MqJY6eUOzxffSvr8lbw9c-jEvJ-J0ugR5Yv62L3uHxQJ0m0uA7CISzIydfussh9Jsy5asPB9YjS1DcLcLUOatJ3lJEYpiUH1IDA47yMygBE1bGfS7P~jCu8PL41vX19KLBPYyyz57V2jEXErzxl8K0QOsLaEvd0goGFT13ZFIbx7MEw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-mu12.gif\" />\u2060</span>, Dec. =+17\u00b046\u203239\u2033.33 (J2000.0), where 1 arcsec corresponds to 6.17 kpc at the redshift of this cluster.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545219 id=\"16545219\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-9>3.9 MACS J1149.5+2223</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This cluster was first analysed by us (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b106\" data-open=\"b106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst 2009</a>) noting several large blue spiral galaxy images which are clearly visible near the central brightest cluster galaxy (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f17\" data-open=\"f17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 17</a>). Shortly after, spectroscopic redshifts were published (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b89\" data-open=\"b89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2009</a>) in full agreement with the predictions of our analysis: we assumed <em>z</em>\u2243 1.5 for the spiral-galaxy (system 1), and <em>z</em>\u2243 2 for the outer blue images (system 3 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f17\" data-open=\"f17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 17</a>), which were later verified to be at <em>z</em> = 1.49 and 1.89, respectively. Many other faint lensed galaxies are also visible, most of which we have been able to securely identify as belonging to 10 sets of multiply-lensed background galaxies (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f17\" data-open=\"f17\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 17</a>) (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b106\" data-open=\"b106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst 2009</a> for more details). We find that the critical curves for a source redshift of <em>z</em>\u2243 2 enclose a mass of (1.71 \u00b1 0.20) \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>, and have an equivalent Einstein radius of 27 \u00b1 3 arcsec.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545221 id=\"16545221\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-10>3.10 MACS J1423.8+2404</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The galaxy cluster MACS J1423.8+2404 (<em>z</em> = 0.543) was recently analysed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. (2010)</a>, finding three sets of multiply-lensed galaxies. System 1 here was spectroscopically measured by them to be at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 2.84 and system 2 here was spectroscopically measured by them to be at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 1.78. We incorporate these images in order to fully constrain our model, with an additional locally lensed arc found here (system 3). The corresponding critical curves for a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2 are overlaid in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f19\" data-open=\"f19\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 19</a>, enclosing a mass of (1.3 \u00b1 0.40) \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> and yielding an effective Einstein radius of \u03b8<sub>e</sub> = 20 \u00b1 2 arcsec. This Einstein radius is in agreement with that quoted by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. (2010)</a>, yet the mass is lower than quoted by them, but fully agrees with the mass\u2013critical area relation seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f27\" data-open=\"f27\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 27</a>, which supports our measurement. The reference centre of our analysis is fixed near the centre of the ACS frame at RA =<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-mu13.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=w-zwbnpJFRK~~Q~-W0MfR7K-eVvfiP14H5MgdA2hMbgADzVPFRJaIv~PkbpNjsTSbIWjOf0MmS3RB~Ag0c5P6vPCBToxDTucNrSZKT0CjjMtbwL8kn5pO-5wNJvHmvUt9M6-sYOd1NKkUeDmvTn3LtugukfTCeQhxNXmh8KCWYacY7G7HEW56aZC7wOpAFsOpDKk~xp-gR8932JFm68zxOKwR~AKRtRxNzxAsrJ3KvuDmTDHxDK5G6WopmLmtQc58GgNxElLbuixTWxCi5Ws14Xrd81Q8-5DmbKZp3PDpIu48a~3AsM6WXN7padwGOxePdb3HO4hnm9FgUyuhYzl2g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-mu13.gif\" />\u2060</span>, Dec. =+24\u00b005\u203200\u2033.23 (J2000.0), where 1 arcsec corresponds to 6.40 kpc at the redshift of this cluster.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545223 id=\"16545223\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-11>3.11 MACS J2129.4\u22120741</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the galaxy cluster MACS J2129.4\u22120741 (<em>z</em> = 0.589) various arcs are seen throughout the image. One spectacular system consists of six lensed images in similar colours as the cluster members (system 1; see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f21\" data-open=\"f21\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 21</a>). We use this system and the large arc (system 2) farther away from the centre to fully constrain the model. Estimating that the outer blue arc (system 2) is at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2\u20132.5, correspondingly, the six-times lensed galaxy of system 1 is at a redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 1\u20131.5. The outer critical curve, corresponding to system 2 encloses an area of an effective radius of \u03b8<sub>e</sub> = 37 \u00b1 2 arcsec and a mass of 3.4<sup>+0.6</sup><sub>\u22120.3</sub>\u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. The reference centre of our analysis is fixed at RA =<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-mu14.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=CGtSikw1axAi0C1MOVWgP8PpbMwYjwPsL38MouBEIOm~80BCc03QsimA570eWrHlGVtDuH3chpvhYwEEXRThMI49uTIeAdnTXEaffKW9-pYKACkBlbBbquBYsrk9Lj6Bf00gkldH6ktAIv48i-LuedXgCLJYWp~1cBRRAL~t8leMhRGh56J8h1QYdQ0600GSHJIwZZcwMZjF~0a7b6VZQJn8XlHM9-Az~dwWrA4awLQtQP8tlexjv4bjiBXU2ILerRhcIJQaGmhkx6Lryde-qYG7~ZljW3b4OGII7rZUbFcl0fENyw-dke2T9bvhXVer0ESpUIJjEafP1r5tgVf6Tw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-mu14.gif\" />\u2060</span>, Dec. =\u221207\u00b041\u203227\u2033.28 (J2000.0), where 1 arcsec corresponds to 6.66 kpc at the redshift of this cluster.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545225 id=\"16545225\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-12>3.12 MACS J2214.9\u22121359</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The galaxy cluster MACS J2214.9\u22121359 (<em>z</em> = 0.503) comprises several prominent large blue arcs, 4 of which we match as system 1 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f23\" data-open=\"f23\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 23</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f35\" data-open=\"f35\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">35</a>). This system might include an additional image, with mirror symmetry to 1.4, if the nearby foreground object is prominently included, yet we do not use this image for constraining our model. We estimate the redshift of systems 1 and 2 as <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2, which encloses a mass of (1.25 \u00b1 0.10) \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> in a critical area with an effective Einstein radius of \u03b8<sub>e</sub> = 23 \u00b1 2 arcsec. The reference centre of our analysis is fixed at RA =<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/410/3/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17574.x/2/m_mnras0410-1939-mu15.gif?Expires=1639265755&amp;Signature=3WZqWadV9jamO-6FvOXlGlN5aTv1Vmj1dHEUKYqy5ZB3SsKBgwj0ehdFrCv4RFpoRNKyMNiRwyJrpqWhpinlLVp200ReQhMlzbtozT~mdnDCr07zjf0nvOqw5bVYl~qiHRLytgS6jSw6NmdRRBji6bOjA91i7h~aytmCqYkkI3paHdmvSL-ZYGMtssf6jKQnN7zDQab~LrxLp0Da06WcP27Jadw4GzwyroxaKk020vBJ3ypRL9BEtBmmjhTPbQkdG8QfiYNz~6gG0khzSr7GzDBlcvg7TstY-wLlP6L-mVA4~Qapy57mcTWWpSs6nKuXXBGu~7kjvTT3RQFdyFyctg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0410-1939-mu15.gif\" />\u2060</span>, Dec. =\u221214\u00b0 00\u2032 17.23 (J2000.0), where 1 arcsec corresponds to 6.16 kpc at the redshift of this cluster.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16545227 id=\"16545227\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4>4 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we examine the SL properties of the whole sample. The Einstein radii, enclosed mass and high-<em>z</em> magnifications are listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a> and discussed in the following subsections.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545229 id=\"16545229\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-1>4.1 The Einstein radius distribution</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The 12 clusters have effective Einstein radii in the range, 11\u201355 arcsec, with a median value of 27.5 arcsec (and a mean value of 28 \u00b1 3.6 arcsec), assuming a fixed source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u2243 2 (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f25\" data-open=\"f25\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 25</a>). This corresponds to a range of physical radii, 68\u2013353 kpc, with a median value of 180 kpc, when transforming to the redshift of each lens. In the hierarchical model, large-scale perturbations collapse recently and thus should be found relatively locally. This sample includes very large Einstein radii, exceeding even the most impressive lenses previously studied at lower redshifts as analysed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b13\" data-open=\"b13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst &amp; Barkana (2008)</a>. More recently, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b77\" data-open=\"b77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. (2010b)</a> carefully studied the lensing properties of 20 mainly undisturbed clusters at lower <em>z</em>, selected to have SL features in <em>Hubble</em> data and measured X-ray data, for which their mean Einstein radius is \u03b8<sub>e</sub> = 14.45 arcsec, a factor of \u223c2 smaller than our sample. This difference reflects the larger masses of the MACS subsample that we studied, which is purely X-ray flux selected and restricted to <em>z</em> &gt; 0.5. This MACS sample therefore does not suffer from a lensing-selection bias, but the effect of projection bias must be taken into account when evaluating 2D lensing observations with 3D mass profiles predicted by theory (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b42\" data-open=\"b42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hennawi et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b71\" data-open=\"b71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b83\" data-open=\"b83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sereno, Jetzer &amp; Lubini 2010</a>), as discussed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.4</a> below.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Most of these clusters have resisted analysis by strong lensing, despite the long availability of the <em>Hubble</em> data. Our success in \u2018cracking\u2019 these irregular lenses and defining their critical curves is encouraging for the application of our approach to complex unrelaxed clusters more generally. For such clusters, where the deflection fields are not symmetric, the identification of multiple images must be aided by models that allow for flexibility in describing the mass distribution, as described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a>, free of the strictures imposed by the use of idealized elliptical potentials in conventional models.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545232 id=\"16545232\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-2>4.2 Central mass distributions</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The masses enclosed by the critical curves range from 2.8<sup>+0.2</sup><sub>\u22120.1</sub>\u00d7 10<sup>13</sup> to (7.4 \u00b1 0.5) \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> with a median value of 1.9 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> and a mean value of 2.4<sup>+0.8</sup><sub>\u22120.2</sub>\u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> as shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>. These are calculated for each cluster by integrating the surface mass density distribution within the 2D model critical curve, scaled to a source redshift of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2. We examine the relation between these Einstein masses, <em>M</em><sub>Ein</sub>, enclosed within the critical curves, and the effective Einstein radii derived above. Theoretically, this should of course simply scale as <em>M</em><sub>Ein</sub>\u221d\u03b8<sup>2</sup><sub>e</sub> for symmetric lenses. Here the lenses are not symmetric, but as can be seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f27\" data-open=\"f27\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 27</a> the quadratic relation is tightly followed, indicating that asymmetry is not very significant in terms of the mass distribution, and furthermore the measured or assumed redshifts of <em>z</em>\u2243 2 for the relevant systems is a reliable estimate. In fact, we see clearly in that the 2D mass distributions are in general noticeably rounder than the critical curves which are very sensitive to substructure, as can be seen by comparing the 2D mass distributions with the critical curves, shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1  f24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1  f24\" data-open=\"f1  f24\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Figs 1\u201324</a>. Further encouragement for the accuracy of SL mass estimates is presented in recent work by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b66\" data-open=\"b66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Meneghetti et al. (2010b)</a>, showing that SL methods based on parametric modelling are accurate at the level of few per cent at predicting the projected inner mass.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b77\" data-open=\"b77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. (2010b)</a> found a mean mass of 1.95 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> enclosed mass (within <em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc) for their sample of 20 clusters, while <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b88\" data-open=\"b88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. (2005)</a> examined the mass distribution of 10 X-ray-selected clusters, and found a similar mean mass of 1.86 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b77\" data-open=\"b77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. 2010b</a>). These values are in good agreement with our sample median mass (1.9 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>) and slightly lower than our sample mean mass, which is boosted by few extremely massive clusters (e.g. MACS J0717.5+3745).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We examine the behaviour of the central mass-to-light ratio, <em>M</em>/<em>L<sub>B</sub></em>, with the Einstein radius and shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f28\" data-open=\"f28\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 28</a>. The luminosity is summed over all cluster sequence galaxies identified as described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a>. A clear correlation is obtained, such that <em>M</em>/<em>L<sub>B</sub></em> increases with the Einstein radius, and with values quite typical of other massive clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b82\" data-open=\"b82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sarazin 1988</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b79\" data-open=\"b79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Rines et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b63\" data-open=\"b63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Medezinski et al. 2010</a>). This scaling towards higher <em>M</em>/<em>L<sub>B</sub></em> provides confidence in our method. At the high-mass end, our result is similar to the peak <em>M</em>/<em>L</em> found in the detailed weak-lensing profile studies of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b63\" data-open=\"b63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Medezinski et al. (2010)</a>. Measuring <em>M</em>/<em>L<sub>B</sub></em> in high-<em>z</em> clusters is also of interest for the added insight into the amount of DM initially associated with individual galaxies as compared with the overall cluster DM component (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b82\" data-open=\"b82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sarazin 1988</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545236 id=\"16545236\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-3>4.3 The magnification distribution</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">As can be seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>, most of the sample clusters provide large regions (\u22652.5 arcmin<sup>2</sup>) of highly magnified (&gt;10\u00d7) sky, useful for the search of the first stars and galaxies (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b102\" data-open=\"b102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zackrisson et al. 2010</a>). One has to be cautious when making such a statement since unlike the critical curves and the enclosed mass, the magnification is sensitive to the mass profile which requires source redshift estimation for several sources, which we have here for only a few clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a>). Still, as explained in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2\"></span><a href=\"#ss2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2</a>, reasonable constraints are put on the mass profile slope by the image-plane minimization, which generally has a broad minimum at the same point in the parameter space where the slope is also approximately correct. In addition, we are able to put a lower boundary on the high magnification area, by choosing the steeper profiles, which naturally generate lower magnifications, or by assuming a boosted redshift for the main multiply-lensed system decreasing the lensing distance ratio for high-<em>z</em> galaxies. Thus, we constrain the area of high magnification for a high-<em>z</em> source at the current limit of <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 8, showing that most of this sample clusters are excellent targets for high-<em>z</em> galaxy searches due to these large high-magnification areas and lens power. We estimate, based on previously analysed clusters (e.g. Cl 0024+1654, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b108\" data-open=\"b108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009b</a>; MACS J1149.5+2223, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b106\" data-open=\"b106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst 2009</a>; MACS J0717.5+3745, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009a</a>), that in practice the areas of high magnification are about 10\u201320 per cent higher than the lower limits presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>, with an upper limit of about 40\u201350 per cent.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545238 id=\"16545238\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-4>4.4 Comparison with <em>\u039b</em>CDM</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We generally follow <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b13\" data-open=\"b13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst &amp; Barkana</a> (2008; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b81\" data-open=\"b81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sadeh &amp; Rephaeli 2008</a>) in constructing the theoretically predicted distribution of Einstein radii. In particular, we adopt the Navarro\u2013Frenk\u2013White parameters measured by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b70\" data-open=\"b70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Neto et al. (2007)</a> for simulated haloes, although we reduce <em>c</em><sub>N</sub> by 10 per cent according to the results of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b26\" data-open=\"b26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. (2008)</a> who used the more recently measured values of the cosmological parameters. Studies based on large numerical simulations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b103\" data-open=\"b103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zhao et al. 2003</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b104\" data-open=\"b104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b37\" data-open=\"b37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gao et al. 2008</a>) have found for massive haloes a rather weak decline of <em>c</em><sub>N</sub> with increasing redshift; we neglect this decline, which renders our results (in terms of the disagreement with observations) conservative. We then correct the concentration parameter distribution using <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b42\" data-open=\"b42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hennawi et al. (2007)</a> to obtain the effective parameters for the population of clusters observed in projection. Note though that here we are considering a sample selected by X-ray flux (not lensing cross-section), so there is no lensing bias, but there still is the projection bias; this refers to the fact that when haloes are seen in projection (at randomly distributed angles), a different effective projected <em>c</em><sub>N</sub> is measured than would be obtained from a spherical analysis of the halo density profile. In particular, projection increases the mean <em>c</em><sub>N</sub> and adds substantially to the scatter compared to the distribution of the spherically measured <em>c</em><sub>N</sub>. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b70\" data-open=\"b70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Neto et al. (2007)</a> split their halo sample into two groups (\u2018relaxed\u2019 and \u2018unrelaxed\u2019) and analysed the statistics of each group separately, so we do the same, and in the end combine the two groups according to their relative numbers in the simulation by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b70\" data-open=\"b70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Neto et al. (2007)</a>, obtaining our predicted results for the total, combined population of haloes. This can then be compared with the observed sample, which does not select for relaxed clusters but includes both relaxed and unrelaxed ones.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to approximately simulate a flux-selected sample, we need to convert <em>L</em><sub>X</sub> to halo mass. We use the power-law relation from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b75\" data-open=\"b75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Reiprich &amp; B\u00f6hringer</a> (1999; with an updated Hubble constant), along with the observed scatter of <em>L</em><sub>X</sub> for a given mass, which we model as a lognormal distribution with a typical scatter that corresponds to a factor of 1.5. Note that this observed relation is based on <em>M</em><sub>500</sub>, while the results from the above simulations refer to <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>, so we must include the relation between <em>M</em><sub>500</sub> and <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> which is itself a function of <em>c</em><sub>N</sub>. An important caveat is that the observed <em>L</em><sub>X</sub>\u2013<em>M</em> relation was measured for relaxed clusters (whose mass could be estimated from the X-ray emission assuming hydrostatic equilibrium). We expect that unrelaxed clusters would tend to have an unusually high <em>L</em><sub>X</sub> for a given mass (for example in a post-merger phase; e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b78\" data-open=\"b78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ricker &amp; Sarazin 2001</a>), which would insert more low-mass clusters within the sample than we assume, leading to smaller predicted Einstein angles, increasing the discrepancy between the theory and the observations (again making our results conservative).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">On the other hand, it should be noted that much of the scatter in the <em>L</em><sub>X</sub>\u2013<em>M</em> relation probably arises from cool cores in the centre (since it is significantly reduced if the inner core is excised), implying a possible bias towards relaxed and more concentrated systems. However, such a bias seems less probable in our case due to the high X-ray luminosity, the relatively high redshift and the clear spread-out appearance of most of the clusters analysed here.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The observed properties of each halo (flux, Einstein radius distribution, etc.) change slowly with redshift, so to simplify the calculation, we approximate the clusters as all lying at a typical redshift <em>z</em> = 0.55. However, the halo abundance changes rapidly with redshift, so we calculate the integrated halo mass function for all haloes observed at <em>z</em> &gt; 0.5, in the fraction of the sky corresponding to the MACS survey (around a quarter of the sky). We use the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b85\" data-open=\"b85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sheth &amp; Tormen (1999)</a> formula, which accurately fits the halo mass function (i.e., the distribution of <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>) measured in simulations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This halo mass function was convolved with the <em>c</em><sub>N</sub> distribution to obtain the distribution of <em>M</em><sub>500</sub>, and then add the <em>L</em><sub>X</sub>\u2013<em>M</em><sub>500</sub> scatter in order to obtain the halo mass function corresponding to selection by a given minimum flux. Since the <em>L</em><sub>X</sub>\u2013<em>M</em><sub>500</sub> relation is not strictly valid for unrelaxed clusters, we only use the power law and the scatter from this relation but allow some flexibility in the normalization, choosing an effective minimum flux that corresponds to a predicted abundance of 12 clusters (as in the observed sample). This is reasonable also since we are interested here in testing the predicted \u03b8<sub>e</sub> distribution, not in testing the predicted cluster abundance. Note that the flux selection does not affect the distribution of the very highest \u03b8<sub>e</sub> values, since all clusters within the survey solid angle at <em>z</em> &gt; 0.5 that can produce the largest values of \u03b8<sub>e</sub> will be well above the flux threshold.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Given our predicted, X-ray-selected mass function in terms of <em>M</em><sub>500</sub>, we must convolve it with the \u03b8<sub>e</sub> distribution of each halo of mass <em>M</em><sub>500</sub>. From the simulations, we have the <em>c</em><sub>N</sub> distribution (and thus also the \u03b8<sub>e</sub> and <em>M</em><sub>500</sub> distribution) for a given <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>, but we can invert this conditional probability using Bayes\u2019 theorem. Note that the <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> to <em>M</em><sub>500</sub> conversion should not really include the projection bias that is included in \u03b8<sub>e</sub>, but having two different <em>c</em><sub>N</sub> distributions for each <em>M</em><sub>200</sub> would makes things far more complicated. Our simplification of using a single <em>c</em><sub>N</sub> distribution is reasonable since the projection bias typically affects <em>M</em><sub>500</sub> (for a given <em>M</em><sub>200</sub>) only by 15 per cent. Also, since <em>c</em><sub>N</sub> affects both <em>M</em><sub>500</sub> and \u03b8<sub>e</sub> in the same direction, the effect on our final result (which derives \u03b8<sub>e</sub> for a given <em>M</em><sub>500</sub>) is much smaller.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our predicted \u03b8<sub>e</sub> distribution is compared to the observations in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f26\" data-open=\"f26\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 26</a>. We compare the two cumulative distributions <em>N</em>(&gt; \u03b8<sub>e</sub>), that is, the total number of clusters expected above \u03b8<sub>e</sub>, where the theoretical distribution has been normalized (as noted above) to agree with the total of 12 clusters in the sample. The observed distribution clearly lies at higher Einstein radii compared with the predicted distribution. One indication of this is the most discrepant cluster, J0717.5+3745, with \u03b8<sub>e</sub> = 55 arcsec. The theoretical calculation yields a probability of only 3.4 per cent of finding such a large \u03b8<sub>e</sub> in this <em>z</em> &gt; 0.5 cluster sample, giving a significant (though not extreme) 2\u03c3 discrepancy. More generally, the observed distribution resembles the predicted one except offset towards higher angles by about a factor of 1.4 (comparing, for example, the two medians). The standard Kolmogorov\u2013Smirnov (K\u2013S) statistic for comparing two distributions gives a probability of 7.4 per cent that the observed distribution is drawn from the predicted one. This is also around a 2\u03c3 discrepancy, largely independent of the above number since the K\u2013S statistic focuses on the middle portion of the probability distributions and is insensitive to the edges. The relatively low significance of the K\u2013S discrepancy is an inevitable result of the Poisson fluctuations expected with a sample of only 12 clusters.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The discrepancy that we find, of Einstein radii that are too high by about a factor of 1.4, appears smaller than the roughly factor of 2 difference found by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b13\" data-open=\"b13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst &amp; Barkana (2008)</a>. This may be explained at least partially by the difference between a lensing selected and an X-ray-selected sample. A more robust comparison would be possible with an X-ray-selected cluster sample in which the clusters have reliable virial masses measured using weak lensing. Another caveat is that we have compared the observed Einstein radii with the predictions based on pure DM simulations. The possible effect of baryons on the halo density profile has been difficult to study with simulations, since hydrodynamic simulations that produce a large effect do so along with a central baryon concentration that disagrees with observations and is due to the \u2018overcooling\u2019 problem in simulations. Analytical models suggest that even without producing a central baryon concentration, the complex coupled history of baryon and DM accretion may allow the baryons to significantly affect the final central density profile, potentially alleviating the discrepancy at least partially (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Barkana &amp; Loeb 2010</a>). On the other hand, recent simulations suggest that the discrepancy actually increases when active galactic nucleus feedback is taken into account to overcome the overcooling problem (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b27\" data-open=\"b27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Duffy et al. 2010</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=16545247 id=\"16545247\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-5>4.5 Effects of uncertainties on the results</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this work, we determine the Einstein radii and projected masses for the 12 clusters of the <em>z</em> &gt; 0.5 MACS sample, and compare these to simulations. We make use of our well-established modelling method to identify many sets of multiply-lensed images, which are in turn used to constrain the models, and determine the Einstein radii and projected masses for <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u2243 2. Typical uncertainties in the source redshift estimates of \u0394<em>z</em>\u00b1 0.5 impose only minor uncertainties on the comparison with \u039bCDM. First, such an uncertainty does not enable a unique determination of the profile slope, which we do not attempt to fully constrain here since both the Einstein radius and the projected mass are indifferent to the mass profile slope and are determined by the data. Secondly, overestimating a source redshift would in practice increase the projected mass and the observed Einstein radius for a source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 2, while maintaining the relation seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f27\" data-open=\"f27\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 27</a> and thus resulting only in growth of the discrepancy from \u039bCDM simulations, which are not dependent on the observed mass. On the other hand, underestimating a source redshift would in practice decrease the observed Einstein radius and projected mass for a source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> = 2 by less than 10 per cent, thus insignificantly influencing the results.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16545249 id=\"16545249\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5>5 SUMMARY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The MACS <em>z</em> &gt; 0.5 sample has proven to be of great value for many very different studies spanning the X-ray through radio spectrum. We have extracted additional useful information from this sample by solving the strong lensing for these clusters. Previous discoveries from this sample include the largest lensed images of a highly magnified distant spiral galaxy (MACS J1149.5+2223; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b106\" data-open=\"b106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin &amp; Broadhurst 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b89\" data-open=\"b89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2009</a>), the largest known lens (MACS J0717.5+3745; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b107\" data-open=\"b107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zitrin et al. 2009a</a>), lensed submillimetre sources (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b93\" data-open=\"b93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Takata et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b7\" data-open=\"b7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Borys et al. 2004</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b3\" data-open=\"b3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Berciano Alba et al. 2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and another \u2018bullet cluster\u2019 (MACS J0025.4\u22121222; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brada\u010d et al. 2008b</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We presented mass models and the corresponding critical curves for the 12 high-<em>z</em> X-ray luminous clusters of the sample via strong-lensing analysis in <em>HST</em>/ACS images. Several of these clusters have only a few strongly lensed images and corresponding low masses and Einstein radii, while most are very massive and rich with multiply-lensed arcs due to large critical area and high lens power. The equivalent Einstein radii of this sample range from 11 to 55 arcsec with a median value of \u224328 arcsec (similar to the mean value) or 180 kpc. The corresponding masses enclosed within these curves range from 2.8<sup>+0.2</sup><sub>\u22120.1</sub>\u00d7 10<sup>13</sup> to 7.4 \u00b1 0.5 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> with a median value of 1.9 \u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> and a mean value of 2.4<sup>+0.8</sup><sub>\u22120.2</sub>\u00d7 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. We find that the enclosed mass follows tightly the quadratic relation with the equivalent Einstein radius, indicating that the deviation from symmetry is not prominent in these clusters and that our measurements are highly accurate given the measured or assumed redshifts. In addition, we have shown that <em>M</em>/<em>L<sub>B</sub></em> increases as expected with the scale size of the system or Einstein radius.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We compare these results to the predictions of \u039bCDM taking into account projection biases and find that these predictions fall short of our measured Einstein radii by a factor of \u22431.4. In addition, the standard K\u2013S statistic gives a probability of only 7.4 per cent that the observed distribution is drawn from the predicted one, corresponding to a \u223c2\u03c3 discrepancy. It is apparent that the observed Einstein radii and implied high masses are not likely at high redshifts in the context of the \u039bCDM model when no lensing-selection biases are involved, showing again possible tension with the prediction of the standard model. Finally, as a result of their unrelaxed mass distributions, most of these clusters cover a very large area (&gt;2.5 arcmin<sup>2</sup>) of high magnification (&gt;10\u00d7) making them primary targets for high-<em>z</em> galaxy searches, for which substantial <em>HST</em> time will shortly be forthcoming.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">It should be acknowledged that theoretical predictions may clearly entail further uncertainties than those taken into account here, and a revised and more thorough analysis is needed in order to obtain higher significance results once source redshifts are available. Such comparisons should also be independently applied to other large samples, so that a significant number of clusters are compared to the \u039bCDM model in order to statistically support any claimed discrepancy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank the anonymous reviewer of this work for very useful comments. AZ acknowledges Eran Ofek and Salman Rogers for their publicly available Matlab scripts used in part of this work. AZ thanks Sharon Sadeh for useful discussions and Elinor Medezinski for sharing some Subaru data. This research is being supported by the Israel Science Foundation (ISF) grant 1400/10. RB is supported by the ISF grant 823/09. ACS was developed under NASA contract NAS 5-32865. This research is based on observations provided in the HLA, which is a collaboration between the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI/NASA), the Space Telescope European Coordinating Facility (ST-ECF/ESA) and the Canadian Astronomy Data Centre (CADC/NRC/CSA). Part of this work is based on data collected at the Subaru Telescope, which is operated by the National Astronomical Society of Japan. Figures from our previous papers republished here are reproduced by permission of the AAS.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=16545256 id=\"16545256\" class=\"backreferences-title js-splitscreen-backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list js-splitview-ref-list\"><div content-id=\"b1\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"b1\"><div class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"b1\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\">\r\n<div class=\"name\"><div analysis. Part of the following data are based on <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al.</a> (2007; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>). Column 3: Effective Einstein radius, in arcsec (simply the square root of the area enclosed within the critical curves divided by \u03c0); Column 4: Effective Einstein radius, in kpc, for <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2. An uncertainty of \u0394<em>z</em>\u00b1 0.5 in the estimated source redshift results in a typical \u223c10 per cent deviation in the lensing distance ratio, and usually up to such deviation also in the Einstein radii. Column 5: Mass enclosed within the critical curves, in 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. The quoted errors correspond to the different models. They do not include the source redshift uncertainty where exists. An uncertainty of \u0394<em>z</em>\u223c 0.5 can cause a typical mass uncertainty of <sup>+50</sup><sub>\u221210</sub> per cent; Column 6: <em>M</em>/<em>L<sub>B</sub></em>, in (M/L)<sub>\u2299</sub>, fluxes were converted to luminosities using the Luminous Red Galaxies (LRG) template described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ben\u00edtez et al. (2009)</a>; Column 7: Lower limit of the highly magnified (&gt;10\u00d7) area for a high-<em>z</em> source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 8, in arcmin<sup>2</sup>; and Column 8: image-plane rms, in arcsec; for more details, see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>."}, "Pandas format": {"Table 2": {"Status": "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Table correctly loaded": "", "Lens Kind": "9"}, "Table map to MasterLens "Complete", "Action": "Processed via pandas", "Inspection": {"Notes": {"Skip cause table not important": ""}}}}}, "Table set 1": {"Link": "https://academic.oup.com/view-large/16545190", "Response": Part of the following data are based on <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span>Ebeling et al. (2007; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span>Table 1). Column 3: Effective Einstein radius, in arcsec (simply the square root of the area enclosed within the critical curves divided by \u03c0); Column 4: Effective Einstein radius, in kpc, for <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2. An uncertainty of \u0394<em>z</em>\u00b1 0.5 in the estimated source redshift results in a typical \u223c10 per cent deviation in the lensing distance ratio, and usually up to such deviation also in the Einstein radii. Column 5: Mass enclosed within the critical curves, in 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. The quoted errors correspond to the different models. They do not include the source redshift uncertainty where exists. An uncertainty of \u0394<em>z</em>\u223c 0.5 can cause a typical mass uncertainty of <sup>+50</sup><sub>\u221210</sub> per cent; Column 6: <em>M</em>/<em>L<sub>B</sub></em>, in (M/L)<sub>\u2299</sub>, fluxes were converted to luminosities using the Luminous Red Galaxies (LRG) template described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span>Ben\u00edtez et al. (2009); Column 7: Lower limit of the highly magnified (&gt;10\u00d7) area for a high-<em>z</em> source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 8, in arcmin<sup>2</sup>; and Column 8: image-plane rms, in arcsec; for more details, see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span>Table 1.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t2\" data-id=\"t2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary and results of the SL analysis. Part of the following data are based on <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span>Ebeling et al. (2007; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span>Table 1). Column 3: Effective Einstein radius, in arcsec (simply the square root of the area enclosed within the critical curves divided by \u03c0); Column 4: Effective Einstein radius, in kpc, for <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 2. An uncertainty of \u0394<em>z</em>\u00b1 0.5 in the estimated source redshift results in a typical \u223c10 per cent deviation in the lensing distance ratio, and usually up to such deviation also in the Einstein radii. Column 5: Mass enclosed within the critical curves, in 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>. The quoted errors correspond to the different models. They do not include the source redshift uncertainty where exists. An uncertainty of \u0394<em>z</em>\u223c 0.5 can cause a typical mass uncertainty of <sup>+50</sup><sub>\u221210</sub> per cent; Column 6: <em>M</em>/<em>L<sub>B</sub></em>, in (M/L)<sub>\u2299</sub>, fluxes were converted to luminosities using the Luminous Red Galaxies (LRG) template described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span>Ben\u00edtez et al. (2009); Column 7: Lower limit of the highly magnified (&gt;10\u00d7) area for a high-<em>z</em> source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u223c 8, in arcmin<sup>2</sup>; and Column 8: image-plane rms, in arcsec; for more details, see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span>Table 1.</p></div> </div><div
